content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												As a long time Age of Mythology die hard, it begs the question just what is an "Extended Edition"? Age of Empires II was just known as being "HD" so what does it mean here? Honestly, very very little, for some nothing at all even. But does that stop it from being worth it at all? Asking this old fan, I'd like to think so... depending.Pros:+ Classic gameplay intact+ Readily includes The Titans expansion and Golden Gift extra+ New visual updates work+ Steam workshop+ Online interface and scenario sharing simple+ Developers keen to update+ New Tale of the Dragon expansion coming over a decade later+ Prostagma!Cons:- Multiplayer servers regularly don't display properlly- Online lag, sometimes difficult to know who has the connection issue- Visual updates minor at best- Nothing has really been "extended", Age of Empires II HD had a better, more reflective title...- ...and as a result the full price tag is too highSummery:This new version is at the end of the day is still classic Age of Mythology and has aged very well gameplay wise (despite some obvious old graphical quirks) in a landscape where real-time base building strategy is not as prevelant as it once was. Being on Steam and the perks that it brings with it (intergrated online community, workshop, future updates) with all the content is the easiest way to play today. However, even after a some time, the multiplayer issues are still noticable, in fact for some it may even be a deal breaker. Speaking of which, despite my overall praise, the game is not updated all that much making the 20+ price tag for most regions outright steep so even if like me you are a long time fan, a sale being your best option. Thankfully that does come regularly. Overall the package is worth a buy for the right lower price by your own standard and the developers do have plans to update the game beyond simply another expansion (visuals, balance, servers), I myself will update this review a period following the release of the expansion as some of these issue are very important and should have been ironed out sonner, in the case of online. Still, in the meantime what we've got at the end of the day is classic Age of Mythology.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is an RTS that has in my opinion stood the test of time.  First and foremost this game is related almost directly to the Age of Empires collection. The big difference is the injection of Mythology and Gods instead of historical civilizations like in Age of Empires. A few different things have been changed but you will see about the same formulas being practiced.When I first started playing this game it was almost ten years ago. I had very slow internet but thankfully found this solid game on disk. I was amazed with the quality and the single player replayability. One of my favorite things is the simple and fun editor where you can make your own maps or your own challenges. I would mostly roleplay in which I would make up different battles and very own campaign. It was very satisfying when I could put time into my own ideas.I have always liked the resource race in this game as well where you start by hunting then move up to farming or knowing when to get that next woodcutting or mining upgrade. Managing your economy with your military plays a very large part too. There are many small things in this game that make it feel very well done, as an example when your units are upgraded it updates the armor and weapon textures. Little things like that have always appealed to me while playing because it makes me feel like the developers really cared about this game. I read about how the developers argued for days over the god powers to make sure they were balanced. I believe that's called making a good game to were you care so much about the fairness you push yourself and others that hard.Skybox is another story. I enjoy the fact steamworks is now into the game and instant modifications can be applied that enhance the way I play the game but they have done an "ok" job. The price is a little to much for a game that is this old. Right now is a sale for around $7 and I would recommend you buy it at a time like this but $30 on the other hand is just too much when the disk has been in the bargin bin for half a decade. I could go on about the desync issues but in the end I will recommend this game in its current state.Honestly I am just really happy this is on Steam. I have met so many of die hard fans that I would have never met playing offline so very long ago. It really makes me glad that the community still cares and likes to have a good time with this awesome relic.Thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 19 of 33 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												I liken these recent updated Ensemble/Microsoft classics to buying a Ferrari full of puppies and pizza, they're that much fun. Take some of the best games from our gaming history, update them to work well on modern machines including the multiplayer components, then blow them out with a giant list of modern features like cloud save, achievements, trading cards, workshop, stats and on and on, sell them for a reasonable price and here we are, with a game that I will play until the end of my days.You don't get nearly as many wide-eyed blissful moments with gaming or with most other things in your adult years compared to your childhood, but that's exactly how I felt 30 minutes into playing this updated version, like a kid on Christmas morning. While I may seem a little over the top in my effusive praise, look here; Ensemble is my favorite developer of all time, Age of Empires II and Age of Mythology are among my favorite games of all time, and these updated versions of those games tick every box I need them to tick and then some. This is pure gaming perfection as far as I'm concerned.

												Been playing the original constantly for the past 10 years but this "HD" remake is terrible. Apart from the fatal crashes half way through single-player random maps where the game just restarts for no reason, the graphics additions actually make things worse. With the new water, you can barely see fish through it, or units hiding in the water on the shore, the bloom is bad quality (even if you have a GTX Titan), the models (which haven't been HD'd) just don't suit the new lighting, they look all bubbly/oversmoothed and horrible, and the dynamic shadows look bad. I'm usually a graphics nut but I had to turn it all off and it's still ugly / hard to read. It's like some guy had this great water shader and was like "hey we could stick it in AoM and call it HD, and we'd better shoehorn in some other crap to make it seem worth it". Going back to the original version.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												EXACTLY the same as the original mythology with extremely, extremely minor detail differences that aren't noticable whatsoever. The graphics are still as bad as they used to be, the glitches haven't been fixed or even touched on, the AI hasn't been improved (so you still have the issue of 50% of your ally's/enemies freezing and doing nothing all match) and it genuinely is NOT extended by any definition. The story is the same, the gameplay is the same, the night/day cycle DOESN'T WORK and despite the massive nolstagic trip out it still has nothing good going for it. I'd consider this a waste of money. There are other games that are much better and there are other developers who don't mislead you who also do genuinely good work, save your money for yourself or for people who deserve it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Having grown up with this game (and lost my original CD) it was absolutely fantastic to see it available on Steam. However I was quite baffled when I saw the game's price tag; to demand 27,99€ for a game that is more than a decade old is absurd, saying it is a HD remake does not even justify the price - graphics are the same as it was back in 2002, but with dynamic shadows and a day/night cycle.If you didn't play Age of Mythology back when it was released I wholeheartedly recommend it as the game features: Great campaign storyline.  Well made characters. Decent balanced factions.  An interesting history menu where you can read about the lore of individual units. Beautiful background music.To this day, I still consider Age of Mythology to be one of the most successful RTS games ever made and to play it again after 12 years really gives me a sense of nostalgia, but if want to buy it I would suggest looking elsewhere as a HD remake does not justify a 27,99€ price tag.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												The original, being a game i've played since I was only 4, has been, and always will be, my favorite game. That being said, this version (Age of Mythology: Extended Edition) has become a close second. The flow of the game feels the same as it did over a decade ago with a few minor touch-ups and improvements. I'll admit it, the graphical overhaul wasn't as "stunning" as i'd hoped it would have been, but, it leaves you with the nostalgic feeling of playing a childhood game once again. I've put thousands of hours into the original version, hundreds into the titans expansion, now, it's time to do the same on the extended! If you're new to Age of Mythology, or god-type games in general, but you really like strategy games, dive into this RTS and sink your teeth in. I guarentee you'll get a mouthfull!

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												This is a great game. I've spent hours playing it and have enjoyed it for years. But, this Extended Edition is a piece of garbage. The game is completely glitched. One of the more innocuous glithces occurs when you click on, say a tree, and drag toward a unit the game will think you clicked on and are commanding the tree; thankfully though the commands will be of the unit, not of the tree. Then, there are the abominable graphical glitches which can, at times, make the game unplayable necessitating a reset. At times the map won't load. These glitches first showed up months ago, it seems the Microsoft Studios are trying their best to make their intent of milking the Age of Mythology till it's lying motionless sprawled across dead grass as obvious as they possibly could. The most apt description of this version is schizophrenic. It will reset in the middle of a game, the entire game will close, the graphics will disintigrate, and all other assortments of frustrations. If anyone is curious my computer can handle games with superior graphics with no issue, the problem is rooted in the version of this game itself.If you want to play this game then buy an old version of it on CD. This version isn't even worth the $4.99 that it'll occasionally be sold for let alone the regular 29.99; it leads to too many irritations. After all, the "improved graphics" are meaningless when the entire Christ forsaken game can't handle them to the point where it glitches to Hell!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Summary - The Chinese expansion is rushed, copy-pasted from existing things, and glitchy. The people who profit from this are not the ones who made the original Age of Mythology.Icons for Chinese buildings are re-used existing ones.Chinese god powers and soldiers are like copies of existing ones, just changed a little bit. For example, the chinese monk is the egyptian priest with a different model, texture, icon and description, and instead of converting animals he converts enemies. He waves his arms and makes the exact same chant, and the cursor turns into an Egyprian Ankh when you mouse-over enemies.Incorrect descriptions - The two Chinese heroes we start with are given Arkantos's description of special powers.Poor story-telling - Unlike the original campaign, the beginning of the Chinese campaign has very little story-telling. You are not introduced to the gods, and you just start already in the second age. We only have a brief introduction to the heroes.At the beginning of the campaign.../(SPOILER)\The heroes have to travel across China because when they realise there's evil afoot, a random peasant tells them to cross china, and so they do with no questions asked.\(SPOILER)/Graphic glitches on my new-ish computer - You can see flames if the ground is behind them, but not if the sky if behind them. When placing walls. the wall segment that is behind another is drawn in front of what is actually in front of it.Glitched first scenario in the Chinese campaign - You start in the Second age, but if you restart you are in the first age.It runs slowly.You can drag a box to select four soldiers and it will tell you you've selected only two, or the "bamboo tree" nearby.My fortified wall upgraded to an earthen wall.I got a steam card of Thor with a really bad picture on it, with the description "The Norse god of lightning". Thor is the god of thunder.This is my review after only getting to the second scenario in the Chinese campaign, because waiting to finish it to write the review would make it too late for the review to be helpful, because it's only just been released. Perhaps it's not their fault that the Chinese are so similar to the other ones, because there are only so many possibilities, and the three original races have already taken a share of the possibilities, but the lacking story-telling and the obviously reused artwork and code make it seem like the people who made it rushed it, or did not enjoy maknig it, or something like that. If it was released as a free mod then it would probably be well recieved, but it's been named an official expansion.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												A good classic RTS game with nice thematics, story, gameplay. Comes with the Titans expansion, which adds up to the game. Also has some improved details in the graphics, compared to the original version.Has a great atmosphere, varied and balanced factions, lots of different units, and a great, massive campaign. There's a friends-only and a global ranked system for multiplayer mode (btw filter by ping before picking your games, since it's an international level).Had several bugs since it came out and some laggy features, but it's noticeable that the support team is working on it, many were fixed. I thought it would be a little cheaper, but although it's a bit expensive, it's totally worth it.

content:

												OBS: Somente sobre a nova expansão, o jogo original é incrível e não tem contras...o original de 2002 eu recomendo, vou falar sobre...Age of Mythology: Tales of the Dragon--> Prós: (5%) - Iniciativa e pequeníssimo esforço de trazer o jogo de volta a ativa depois de uma década e pouco, colocando mais unidades e deuses da mitologia chinesa.--> Contras: (95%) - Tudo, fizeram essa expansão depois de uma noite de bebedeira em Las Vegas, de ressaca. - História da campanha foi horrível, vergonhosa...uma cópia mal feita com a base da engine do jogo original. - Jogabilidade fraquíssima com DEZENAS de erros de programação, bugs e falhas por todos os lados. - Extremamente comercial e superficial, uma vergonha para os fãs. - Nova trilha sonora dos chineses ridícula, pegaram um "Background Music" de meditação chinesa do youtube e simplesmente atiraram ali no jogo...já a trilha sonora original continua fantástica, mas não vem ao caso. - Decepcionante, pela expectativa que foi gerada em cima da nova expansão. - Nem sei porque fizeram uma porcaria dessas, cagou tudo...se vai acrescentar algo novo para um jogo que marcou na história dos games, pelo menos faz algo descente, sem falhas, algo autêntico, dinâmico e surpreendente onde passaria as expectativas de todos os jogadores do game original.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
As far as the game itself is concerned, it's simply an amazing and beloved classic.However, most people would want to purchase it when it's on sale, due to the fact that it's quite overpriced.All in all, I am inclined to believe that Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a very enjoyable game and may offer endless hours of entertainment to both longtime RTS fans and newcomers to the genre and/or franchise.Notable features and additions to the old game, for those who are interested in further info:Updated graphics and textures! Now suitable for higher (e.g. HD) resolutions!Long awaited bugfixes and balance changes!Trading cards!Achievements!Steam Workshop for all kinds of mods (easy to install and upload mods)!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Compelling storyline, diversity in player races/classes, and well thought-out map/level design makes this game the best in the franchise. I just finished playing all three, and I can't get over how they overlooked the idea of having 3 distinct player races have separate strengths and weaknesses that accomodate most playstyles to an RTS. Of course, its "easy" campaign option makes the campaign a rewarding experience as you play through all three classes in 48 scenarios. I haven't really dug into the multiplayer yet, but if I did I would feel more than prepared after such an engaging campaign. If you were thinking about getting into franchises or RTS in general, this is the one in the series to get. AoE 2 is much too difficult for me to recommend right away, and the story in the third is far too bland and uninteresting. If you're struggling or you find it boring, play it on Twitch. If you're lucky, you'll have nice viewers help you through it - it definitely made it more interesting for me to play.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a fun RTS game that allows you to play as different ancient gods and use their different abilities to wipe out your enemies. If you're a super competitive gamer and love trying a bunch of various strategies I would totally recommend this game, this is for you. I haven't played the other Age of Mythology games, so I can't say how accurate this one is, however this was recommended to me by a friend who says it's very accurate. Take that as a third party source, though.This is by no means a bad game, and it excels in what it does. It provides a challenging RTS experience that you can enjoy with friends or on your own. The problem for me comes from the game being a tad too competitive. This might not be a problem for you, and it might actually be a good thing. If that's the case you should get this game, probably when it's on sale. If you share the same opinion as me in this area in that you would rather spend your time goofing off than strategising and micromanaging resources, I would say no, you'd be better off spending your money on something else. That's just me, and I understand a lot of people feel otherwise, but for people like me I have to say no, I don't recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Age of Mythology is one of my all-time favourite games and the only RTS I like. It's easy and intuitive to learn with an amazing soundtrack, varied gameplay and awesome campaign, context, story etc. The game design is flawless. I bought this just to re-experience the campaign. However, I did expect that, given it's "Extended Edition" to have updated graphics and some more features. The game does NOTHING!! I have no interest in the multiplayer but from what I hear it's broken - thus defeating the purpose of its revival. The only hope is improved graphics which it does NOT offer AT ALL. The screenshots are deeply misleading. If anything, the game is worse because of framerate drops and poor optimisation, non-functioning V-sync and other issues. If you haven't played Age of mythology, I strongly urge you to do so, but not at the extortionate price of this wannabe remake.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												UPDATE: I saw people complaining about a terrible glitch with the Chinese factions of everything suddenly being destroyed when the scenario begins and losing immediately because of it. At first I didn't have that problem, I was even able to play a few levels of the Chinese storymode, NOW IT'S DOING IT FOR NOT JUST THE STORYMODE BUT NOW FOR EVERY FACTION AND EVERY RANDOM MAP I TRY TO PLAY!!! WTF!!Let me be clear that I love Age of Empires. It's the best real time strategy game of all time, but compared to earlier entries like Age of Empires 2, AoMythology feels like it's lacking. The growth and movements are a lot slower than I remember them to be, and despite the game being remastered with better graphics of the environment and buildings they are still really poor in terms of units (they're basically a few crude shapes with arms). the system of heroes and myth units put a difficult wrench into the mix of unit advantages, and it seems no matter how much you upgrade they die very quickly unless you have an overwhelming force. The buildings compared to AoE2 are also much weaker. Whereas in AoE2 castles and towers could protect you from all sorts of forces, the defenses in Age of Mythology are practically made of cardboard. It almost makes artillery pointless because so long as you're willing to lose a couple of cheap units you can stab whole fortresses to death in a matter of moments, something you and the enemy could rarely do in Age of Empires 2. There is one thing Age of Mythology has that is better than other titles and that's the learning element. It won't teach much history, but when you click on unit icons it opens up a short description of the unit's stories in mythology for myth units or if it's a human unit it will have a small explanation of that unit's weapons or place in ancient history. Even clicking on a wild animal will bring up it's scientific name and other facts about it. For learning purposes, this is the best part of the game. Something I loved about Mythology is that it had much better and much crazier cheatcodes. I'll never forget the glory that is WUV WOO and O CANADA which spawn a flying purple hippo and a superhero bear with the Canadaian flag on it's back. Yet for some reason, I can't get any of them to work anymore. That's reall disappointing for me because those cheats were amazing. All in all, I bought this game for the nostalgia and the new Chinese faction dlc, but feel it was not worth buying again. I much more recommend Age of Empires 2 because it is faster paced, more balanced, slightly cheaper, and has a lot more cultures to choose from.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												the following reveiew was made originally on jan 30th 2016 but i am cleaning house on my reveiws and proof reading stuff.The price is awful for a game that has aged like fine wine. When I was a kid I had this game for the ds, only difference was it was turn based and it didnt really ruin the game for me... but it made a whole new experience. HOWEVER when I came to this, it kinda ruined it I guess cause it was rts? (ikr? ) but also im sort of a casual player when it comes to ensembles aoe games and i like to face bots that prove a challenge but that I can still beat. In this game, when I play a skirmish, because of the rts and the god powers it makes it a lot harder to do things. The sad thing to me is that you can only use god powers one time in a game. I feel like some god powers should be a cool down thing such as the one lightning bolt , sure it may take like 1 min to cooldown and perhaps a certain amount of favor but maybe that would be a better system.the big pros (and not all of them probably):- Different cultures, they add a lot of diversity to the game.- Titans are awesome and badass, you're screwed though if one's heading towards your base.BIG CONS (and not all of them... maybe?)- Thank god I got this on sale, no way I would pay 30$ for this not even or aoe 1. (Which I think is the best out of them all personally.)- I like the settlements idea for ds wich was turn based but not a whole lot for an rts game however.- AGAIN with the house limit? come on I wanna make a huge sprawling city guys!- Just the way the game is, I dunno I cant get sucked in like aoe 3 or aoe 2 (check my hours guys i got a lot on those)- Now I feel like playing civ 5 (civ 5 is better then civ 6 don't get me started on that opinion) or the ds version instead of this game...unless i play this with a friend.- Finally, the price... really microsoft your going to put this price on this game? From something that probably ensemble studios made too.. who aren't around because of you...

Posted: March 4, 2016
												The first time I launched this game it actually worked fine. However, last night it came time to download an update to it... 6.0MB/6.0 ... DISK READ ERROR ... 121.0MB/121.0MB ... DISK READ ERROR ... An hour later the same ♥♥♥♥ing thing ... I defragmented my harddrive, cleaned my system with ccleaner and did an error check to my harddrive, and after a couple of more hours... NOPE! 0 bytes network usage, 0 bytes disk usage, 100 % completion of the update and... DISK READ ERROR!!! GRRRRRRRRRR!!!!!!!! What the ♥♥♥♥! I've never encountered anything like this before! Why doesn't it let me download an update to it? Why does my PC let me surf the net, chat and write this review even though the steam client doesn't let me complete the download of an important update! If you still consider buying this game after reading this review, you're a ♥♥♥♥ing idiot! I see if I can get a refund for it...EDIT: Wait! What! What! It ACTUALLY, finally managed to download the update after, like, 5-6 hours (and the verification of the game files). I might keep the game afterall (too much trouble trying to get a refund right now), but the review stays negative... All of this is just so sad, Age of Mythology is a really great game as long as it runs and doesn't crash or anything... ♥♥♥♥ing bugs! Made me think my harddrive was going to fail...EDIT: EDIT: FIX THE DAMN UPDATING ISSUE SO THAT THIS NEVER HAPPENS AGAIN!!

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												I've logged more time in AoM than probably any other game ever... except maybe Skyim.This is the end-all-be-all of RTS for me.  I've played every AoE game, Warcraft 2 and 3, and countless hours of Starcraft 2.  Age of Mythology wins.The races have drastic differences in appearance, economy, and combat function.  Combat is more economy focused than Starcraft and Warcraft.  If you've ever played an Age of Empires game than you have a basic understanding of what you're in for, but add way more variety in the races from square 1, add unique research abilities based on the gods you worship, and god powers that can drastically shift the battle at any second.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Single player: RECOMMENDED! No the graphics aren't modern. This is a classic game. One I happened to have missed. And it is awesome good fun, if you like this genre and/or the mythology theme. AoM can be pretty challenging, too. I can't imagine playing on the highest difficulty atm. Which means there is someone out there that will LOVE this game for the challenge that would offer.LAN/multiplayer: NOT RECOMMENDED! OMFG WHYEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE?! /emocide! /homocide!! /genociduhduhduhduh!!! ... /flop!!!1 Yea, it *is* that bad.  Still. Yes. Still that bad. If they haven't fixed it yet, I seriously question if they will fix this ever. Yes, that is sad, since the multiplayer aspect is the whole reason for the extended edition reissue.Any game starts off okay, but as soon as you guys begin to progress at all the game begins to hang/stutter a bit, then it hangs like crazy for 30 seconds at a time and eventually someone will just get booted altogether, which completely ruins the game.It does not matter if you have a decent (or better) gaming rig and a good internet connection set up for a multi-gamer household. I don't know what they messed up, but they did mess something up badly and it makes LAN unplayable. I assume multiplayer (online) would be even worse since I can't even play duo with someone on LAN.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
 Masterpiece. Age of Mythology was the first game I ever played seriously. The interesting and diverse gameplay, the deceptively complex game mechanics, and the lovely graphics for the era all make for a game that is thrilling and incredibly fun to play.This game has a certain charm about it; perhaps because of my experiences playing this game. The graphics may not be those of Fallout 4, The Witcher, or other such Triple-A Titles, but the gamemplay more than makes up for this. A lot of Age of Mythology's fun and diverse gameplay comes from its roster of incredibly diverse pantheons, and within those different gods that have different specialties. No two matches are the same, and playing with friends is incredibly fun.Overall, Age of Mythology was a major part of my childhood and I enjoy it to death. I could not recommend this game more, and it holds a special place in my heart.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												==About the game in general==Age of Mythology is an awesome game... I had a lot of fun back in the ESO days, with tons of scenarios, friendly and good players .The steam version is basically the same game with only a few small things improved, But some problems still remains on the game, like DC's out of nowhere or one player can lag the whole game for everyone.And the launch... Don't even talk about the launch... It was a mess...  The launch scared a lot of people (that explains why the game had a low pop of players in the past months), but for a good reason... It was almost unplayable for a good amount of people. But, at least, they released a lot of fixes.It is somewhat playable... But yeah... you can still get DC from the match and the netcode in general they didn't improved that much, one player can still lag the match. I hope they keep releasing more fixes.I recommend the game, but just remind what i said about those multiplayer issues... They still happen. Edit: The new "expansion" increased the MP DC's and bugs. Beware.==About the new content and exclusive steam version patchs==They made some balance changes to the steam version. That is awesome, the game needed it, because a few gods were dominant, like zeus or isis. They gave some needed buffs and nerfs.Now about the "expansion". I haven't bought the "expansion", but i'm not sure if i will buy it now (will wait a 75% sale). The idea was good, but the final result is pretty mediocre. Some units are just reskins from vanilla/titan units, and units with unique models are pretty bad. It feels like a paid amateur mod.It seems like they didn't put a good effort on it and released it too soon. For now, i'm more happy about the balance changes and i hope they fix the new civilization (op units, bugs, awful models and god portraits).

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												This has got to be one of my all time favorite games, an easy top 10 series (and I have been gaming for about 20 years +).  I have been playing this sinec the beta released!  Yes, that many years ago.  I still have my original discs for them and expansion.  Why buy this again on Steam!?  Because its ♥♥♥♥ing amazing and I believe in supporting the companies you like.  Considering I have gotten several thousand hours of fun play time out of this, yes, they earned another sale from me.  So many different ways you can go and play with friends.  Titan challenges are fun as well.  One of my all time best was a rush with Odin winning in 10 minutes (killing all units and buildings), and making a hard mode CPU forfit in 8.  Not saying I am the worlds best, but this is such a great classic.  9/10 (no game is perfect).

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												I cannot believe I have to give this a negative review.. This was a MARVELOUS game, but Microsoft has proven it likes to take games and mold them into a money printer. And that's what this game turned into. This game has almost no support form my recent beginning to play the game. There is much to despair over multiplayer and this is very unfortunate.My reasons Extended Edition should not be bought:-Lag across the board in multiplayer, regardless of how beefy your computer is, online or LAN-God Powers can desync Online games and make it easy to abuse ranking-Conversion of old maps is made incredibly difficult due to the addition of some stupid 'Alfred' unit-There is no report button anywhere, so if you're getting trolled/bashed, you have to cope or stop playing online-Single Player shows it's problems in cutscenes. Wrong Angles or complete terrain obscurity.-HD simply means, you can't find the fish while trying to fish. And a useless Day/Night cycle, that is never used.-Sometimes things happen for no good reasons, such as finishing a Titan Gate and it disapears.I bought this to relive a classic and play online, sadly, this wasn't the case. Skybox games should never be purchased.

												Played this game when it was first released and loved it. I think this was the game that got me into playing RTS's. Played lots of different ones over the years but this one has always remained a favourite. I often hoped (and still do) that AOM 2 might be in the making. number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I own AOE: Gold Edition and before that I owned the Titans Expansion + Regular game before I lost it. I would have clocked up at least 500 hours in this game in my time. Just stating that in case my hours of game time will help you hold my review to a higher validity. This game is absolute favourite game from the "Age Of..." series. In my opinion this game is superior to any Age of Empires game available, even the second. In fact, this game is honestly superior to any RTS strategy game I've ever played.It has every feature from all of the other "Age Of" games and more. Mythical units? ♥♥♥♥ yes. Fantastic campaigns? ♥♥♥♥ yes. Amazing map editor and scenario creator? ♥♥♥♥ yes. TITANS? ♥♥♥♥ yes! Heroes? ♥♥♥♥ yes. 4 different unique races? ♥♥♥♥ yes. A new resource? ♥♥♥♥ yes. I could go on for ♥♥♥♥ing ever but I won't because spoilers. (I'm too lazy.)In my opinion, AOE2 is only more popular because it is simpler. This game has many, many more features than AOE2 and if you go from AOM to AOE you will start to miss a lot of the amazing features that you start to take for granted once you play AOM.Also the multiplayer in the game is very active.I whole heartedly recommend this game. It is worth well over 30 dollars.Oh, and check out AOMHeaven and share your created campaigns/scenarios/maps/AI's on there for other players to play!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												A misleading title, "Extended Edition"Below is a short list of what the game includes and what it doesn't to help you decide on your purchase. Microsofts development teams for these extended and HD remakes really would benefit from graphic designers, artists or content designers.DOES includes:-Minor new graphics engine changes, allowed for bloom lighting and better day and night cylcing with dynamic shadows.-The options menu contains a few new features which allow the player to zoom the camera out a litte further.-Players have a feature which allows them to intergrate their twitch.tv streamingDOES NOT include:- update graphics, texture, models units or animations- additional gameplay content, game modes, factions,campaign missions or multiplayer map styles- multiplayer fixes, issues addressed- better UI support- better hotkey binding support- better AI and pathingOverall Rating: 3/10The game is still good fun, but unless purchased at the sale price of £5 it isn't worth buying. I'm enjoying the title and its steam intergration, however the game is lacking most features you might expect from an extended version of the game. There are no features included which will extend the life cycle of the title and with poor multiplayer support and a high price tag for an old title, ends up making this purchase only rewarding for those who want to play a classic real-time strategy game by themselves or with a friend at sale time.

number of helpful: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												I have been enjoying this game for quite a long time. Bought the original edition in 2005 and a love affair began. This game is really one of the top RTS of all time with it's unique universe and time setting. The Ancient world has been never made before so nicely and I think several years after it's debut we can still say exactly the same. You have the stunning game modes, you have the outstanding editor, modding is pretty easy, just have a look at the biggets fan site (http://aom.heavengames.com/) where you can find plenty of help and of course the actual products of the hardworking modders. The Extended Edition brang back one of the things that I missed for a while, the Multiplayer mode. ESO was shut down and the game lost it's playerbase a bit, but the revival is finely made and hopefully we are going to see many new faces and of course the old ones. :) Other pro is the fantastic graphic effects. I never imagined that this edition will look that good after I saw the press release pictures. I can only recommend getting it as it's a game that you cant miss before you die.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Age of Mythology was the number one game of my childhood, so when I saw an upcoming remake, I directly bought it, no matter the high cost at the time.After 40 hours of playing, I'm glad to say that the team of AoM:EE has done a great job of keeping the old atmosphere of the game by not changing much, however still making it better through the new functions and new graphics.The huge plus the extended edition delivers is Steam Integration - Finally, we have a functioning community which does not only consist of AoMHeaven, but of a better developed Steam Community with all the Steam Features. The Workshop grants great accessibility to Mods and the recent Updates, the Ranking system, the events and the loads of achievements guarantee long-term playability.The big question: Is it worth the money?If you enjoy real-time strategy and haven't played Age of Mythology before, I would highly recommend buying AoM:EE. It is THE classic real-time strategy game, which is, in my eyes, even better than Age of Empires and the EE with all its features is pretty cheap for a brand new strategy game for you, comparing it to other strategy games on the market.If you have already played AoM, I would not recommend buying it at its current price. It has many new features, but if you know the game already, it's just not worth the money.Buy it, but wait for a major sale.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												It's the exact same game I played a decade ago, just... prettier.  There are some nice visual effects added, but the character models and all of the graphics are the same, and the cutscenes of a decade ago are laughable by modern standards.  That's not necessarily a bad thing, though.  It was a very good RTS a decade ago, and there's nothing wrong with updating the skin while leaving the bones of the game entirely intact.If you're like me, and you've been dying to play this game again (now that it will work on a modern computer), definitely buy it.  In fact, I would recommend it to just about anyone who enjoys a good RTS.  Just maybe wait until the price comes down a bit.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Age of Mythology has always been a great favourite of mine, wasted many thousands of hours on it (and in a good way) I even went as far to create a massive modification/overhaul of it called Expanded Mod for the Titans expansion.However Extended Edition is a very mixed bag, most of the time, the crappy work of the exe by Skybox Labs. and the code itself has caused many issues with lag, OOS etc overtime they have fixed this, but mostly because the small 1k community has coerced them into somewhat fixing it.  Rundown:PROS:+ All the Benefits of The Titans+ Four New Vanilla units (Patch 2.0 onwards) and 1 scenario editor/easter egg unit+ Addition of all extra-optional content by ES themself (Away from Home, +2 RMs, Golden Gift Campaign)+ Some Decent Balance+ Readdition of the Beta Ambient Lighting+ Improved Shadows (now dynamic, render based not .DCL/Texture files)+ Somewhat decent Mod Support, but... NEGS:- Crap Optimization, (run it with footprints + Amb Lights in 1024x768 should get around 45 FPS on most 2009 onwards Comps)- Nothing Spectacular content wise, if you know the Beta, AoE Twitch Livestreams, Alphas and Extra ES-made content.- Many Murky/Cloudy Textures, some texture stuff won't render correctly.- Eh Pathfinding- Still Needs a lot of fixing.- Lack of Dev Support- Almost no active communityYeah only 1k players play Online properly (even though there's 14k playing per 2 weeks, and only some 2-30 people playing non-private MP), even, also via the some 900,000+ purchases (roughly 27 million USD) Dev Support is really whack, so it's obvious that it's a money laundering scheme (MS is pretty infamous for that)Only get it, if your a non-Casual or below Age of Empires fan

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												Just a warning to the people who play COH, Men of War: Assault Squad, DOW, Wargame: Red Dragon, etc. This isn't any of those games by a long shot. Not just graphically, but in the way it works. The way you build your economy matters. It can be tedious at times, but managing the economy the right way to get your units out and be aggressive has some appeal.The multiplayer somewhat good. The lobby is easy to navigate, and matches are quick to find. The games are RUINED by the TERRIBLE lag you get. Everything lags, and the more players you put in, the worse it gets. 1 v 1 has the game stuttering, 2 v 2 has the game going slo mo.Get it if you want a deeper RTS game that is dated, but still good.Pass if you want an action oriented RTS, with as little base building and economy as possible.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												I hate to leave this review since AOM is definetly one of my favorite games (top 5 of all time) but this whole new HD release has been ridiculous. I own the (original) physical disk but since they were releasing this HD version I thought hey I'll buy it here it'll be great to have my old favorite with some shiny new polygons. They made it sound like they nearly redid the game updating the graphics (spoiler it looks almost the same as it used to) but that's neither here nor there you don't buy a 12 year old game for the graphics anyway right you buy it for the gameplay, well......Multiplayer, where to even begin. the short version is it doesn't work. The long version is it's bugged out something crazy random crashes, framedrops you name it. It can barely seem to hold a connection long enough to finish a match with someone. I personally got so fed up with this that I never succefully finished a multiplayer game which is awful because multiplayer back in the day was great. these bugs weren't an issue in the original versionok so just play the single player. Well about that. Sometimes the enemy will just stand next to you non hostile and let you kill them without fighting back at all, sometimes they'll be able to produce way more troops than they should be able to (but you cannot). Your own troops (and sometimes the enemy AI as well) will get stuck between walls or buildings and even if you manually control them they can't seem to figure out how to free themselves leaving forcing you to kill them.this problem is in the main campains as well and where also not in the original version. Finally the last straw that finally prompeted me to write this review the DLC. Now I was so excited when I heard they were making another DLC for this game especially somewhere in Asia, that has huge potiental with the possiblity of all new gods, models  and gameplay. Two out of 3 ain't bad I guess. Everything is a lazy retexture of the 1st expansion (the titans) and from what I've heard is basically a beta. I don't even own the thing so why is this my biggest issue? Because in the middle of playing the main single player campain an popup comes up telling me that I need to download the DLC to activate X (which being the orignial main campain shouldn't even need any DLC). This icon won't even let me exit it taking me to the "main page" with my real game still running in the background basically forcing me to watch my troops die. There seems to be no work around for this, no way to avoid it and no way to return to the game, which leads me to believe this is a compulsory $10 DLC. So yea all in all 9/10 exactly as I rememebered it with a few extra lines up until stage 27 then you can get ♥♥♥♥ed. TL;DR HD version is an embarassing buggy version of the original game with a required $10 DLC that if you don't buy will basically end your game but if you do buy will ruin it with glitches. Oh well, if you buy it I hope you don't enjoy multiplayer or finishing games. Edit: Just kidding do not buy this because of the required DLC you can no longer play the original main campain or the single player. Some stores (like office depot) are still selling the original disk with the titian expansion just go buy that.I wanted to make a quick update to this review since I like to play this game before I go to bed. I mean I used to whatever they did for the latest update makes the entire game♥♥♥♥♥♥the bed when you hit the Mythic age. I'm talking lag so bad the entire game is literally unplayable. I swear if I didn't love this game so much as a kid.......

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Age of Mythology has always been a great favourite of mine, wasted many thousands of hours on it (and in a good way) I even went as far to create a massive modification/overhaul of it called Expanded Mod for the Titans expansion.However Extended Edition is a very mixed bag, most of the time, the crappy work of the exe by Skybox Labs. and the code itself has caused many issues with lag, OOS etc overtime they have fixed this, but mostly because the small 1k community has coerced them into somewhat fixing it.  Rundown:PROS:+ All the Benefits of The Titans+ Four New Vanilla units (Patch 2.0 onwards) and 1 scenario editor/easter egg unit+ Addition of all extra-optional content by ES themself (Away from Home, +2 RMs, Golden Gift Campaign)+ Some Decent Balance+ Readdition of the Beta Ambient Lighting+ Improved Shadows (now dynamic, render based not .DCL/Texture files)+ Somewhat decent Mod Support, but... NEGS:- Crap Optimization, (run it with footprints + Amb Lights in 1024x768 should get around 45 FPS on most 2009 onwards Comps)- Nothing Spectacular content wise, if you know the Beta, AoE Twitch Livestreams, Alphas and Extra ES-made content.- Many Murky/Cloudy Textures, some texture stuff won't render correctly.- Eh Pathfinding- Still Needs a lot of fixing.- Lack of Dev Support- Almost no active communityYeah only 1k players play Online properly (even though there's 14k playing per 2 weeks, and only some 2-30 people playing non-private MP), even, also via the some 900,000+ purchases (roughly 27 million USD) Dev Support is really whack, so it's obvious that it's a money laundering scheme (MS is pretty infamous for that)Only get it, if your a non-Casual or below Age of Empires fan

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												After so many years the game has lost no charm, though it remains largely what it was before, except in one simple way, multiplayer. It adds a whole new challenge to the game, anyway, I aim this review at people who have never played the game before and are wondering "is it for me?"Firstly, a huge part of this game (so huge they put it in the title) is mythology, it has rich, historically accurate features that really add to the game, you can train myth units, and you can also wield God powers, (send lightning down on enemies, and even make an earthquake right in your enemies base.) Before you start a game you have to choose a Major God, such as Zeus, Thor, Loki and others (a total of 12) your major God will determine what units, God Powers, and upgrades you will have.Gameplay - This is a Real time strategy game, one of the very best, you start with a few villagers who can build and gather resources (wood, food, and gold.) There are four ages in which you must advance, the archaic age, the classical age, the heroic age, and finally the mythic age. As you advance through the ages you'll unlock new military units (infantry, archers, and cavalry), as well as myth units (minoutaurs, centaurs, cyclops and loads of others.) Ultimatley your goal is pretty simple... Beat the other guy. Advance faster, make bigger armies, or win in other ways such as building a wonder and defending for ten minutes. So it's quite a tactical game. You can also, right at the end of the final age, build a titan, it is like it sounds, a massive thing that tramples cities like godzilla.Graphics - they're perfectly fine, and nothing more. There is violence in the forms of armies battling it out for domination, but nothing very gorey, and there is no bad language, unless you count "Shkeepan" (you'll understand that joke if you play the game"This is a great game, it has a little bit of a learning curve but can be picked up pretty quick, the best part is that even after so many hours, you still have so much to learn, it provides hours of fun. A couple of down sides - Price: £22.99 is a lot for a game that is 10 years old, don't get me wrong, I've paid more for newer games that aren't as good, but I think it's a little steep. Online games can be a little tough to come by, perhaps if they had a sale then more players would realise the quality of this game.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												A conversation between me and Cydran about Age of Mythology: Extended Edition.AA | Cydran: Was it as well remade as you expected?AA | Cydran: or as you were hoping?Veldar: Well.Veldar: It's the same game, just with the expansion I never got, it feels dated, I can tell there are flaws and comming from C&C generals, a much faster game AoM feels very slow to start, getting your economy right is essential which is fine but I prefer the mirco of C&C to the marco of AoM, but the game still has a special place in my heart as the first game I remember asking for and it being my first PC title.Veldar: I still love it though.AA | Cydran: Very nice. I assume that means that new players going into the version of AoM on Steam might not enjoy it as much as they would if they played the game in the past?Veldar: Well to make a judgement you have to put RTS into two piles:Veldar: Mirco and MarcoVeldar: Micro is the faster games C&C generals and Warcraft 3, matchs should last 5 - 15 minutes.Veldar: Where Macro, games like AoM, AoE 3 and SubCom are more about early economy and massing armies then pitting them against each other.AA | Cydran: I seeVeldar: I prefer Micro so a Macro game feels slower to me, I still very much enjoy it and I'll play the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of it but I know that it's not the best RTS by any means.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												UPDATED REVIEW:This game is still brilliant and it works like a charm. Now that im so many hours into playing I have a few things that I feel I should let you know about (These are just cosmetic issues FYI):1.) The devs of this version added in a new "workers counter" Which displays how many workers are gathering each resource, which is great EXCEPT when you get into the 10,000's of a resource, where the UI doesnt compensate and resize; the counter and the resource value overlap. Not an actual issue it just looks ugly.2.) The graphics have been played with and tweaked slightly and I run them at highest quality. The problem is that where in the original the environment looked lovely and smooth, sometimes in this vesion it can looks very square, again not an issue it just looks ugly.3.) In the write ups there are a few spelling mistakes I've found I dont know if that was this company or the orginal but still. 4.) The day and Night cycle seems pretty pointless to be honest with you, it doesnt really get that dark (obviously) and it often more than not doesnt work properly, instead of fading into darkness it just makes my game flash for a few minutes.Okay thats all really. As it said all cosmetic as I've had no real problems with the game, I just feel like they should be mentioned as they're only issues that exist in the Extended Edition.ORIGINAL REVIEW:I could write a 6 million word praise of this game, but I'll save us all the time and say this:MY FAVORITE GAME FROM CHILDHOOD HAS COME TO SSSTTTEEEAAAMMM!!! :D :D :D :DYeah, I love it! But I loved it before I played it, thanks devs!

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												I hate to leave this review since AOM is definetly one of my favorite games (top 5 of all time) but this whole new HD release has been ridiculous. I own the (original) physical disk but since they were releasing this HD version I thought hey I'll buy it here it'll be great to have my old favorite with some shiny new polygons. They made it sound like they nearly redid the game updating the graphics (spoiler it looks almost the same as it used to) but that's neither here nor there you don't buy a 12 year old game for the graphics anyway right you buy it for the gameplay, well......Multiplayer, where to even begin. the short version is it doesn't work. The long version is it's bugged out something crazy random crashes, framedrops you name it. It can barely seem to hold a connection long enough to finish a match with someone. I personally got so fed up with this that I never succefully finished a multiplayer game which is awful because multiplayer back in the day was great. these bugs weren't an issue in the original versionok so just play the single player. Well about that. Sometimes the enemy will just stand next to you non hostile and let you kill them without fighting back at all, sometimes they'll be able to produce way more troops than they should be able to (but you cannot). Your own troops (and sometimes the enemy AI as well) will get stuck between walls or buildings and even if you manually control them they can't seem to figure out how to free themselves leaving forcing you to kill them.this problem is in the main campains as well and where also not in the original version. Finally the last straw that finally prompeted me to write this review the DLC. Now I was so excited when I heard they were making another DLC for this game especially somewhere in Asia, that has huge potiental with the possiblity of all new gods, models  and gameplay. Two out of 3 ain't bad I guess. Everything is a lazy retexture of the 1st expansion (the titans) and from what I've heard is basically a beta. I don't even own the thing so why is this my biggest issue? Because in the middle of playing the main single player campain an popup comes up telling me that I need to download the DLC to activate X (which being the orignial main campain shouldn't even need any DLC). This icon won't even let me exit it taking me to the "main page" with my real game still running in the background basically forcing me to watch my troops die. There seems to be no work around for this, no way to avoid it and no way to return to the game, which leads me to believe this is a compulsory $10 DLC. So yea all in all 9/10 exactly as I rememebered it with a few extra lines up until stage 27 then you can get ♥♥♥♥ed. TL;DR HD version is an embarassing buggy version of the original game with a required $10 DLC that if you don't buy will basically end your game but if you do buy will ruin it with glitches. Oh well, if you buy it I hope you don't enjoy multiplayer or finishing games. Edit: Just kidding do not buy this because of the required DLC you can no longer play the original main campain or the single player. Some stores (like office depot) are still selling the original disk with the titian expansion just go buy that.I wanted to make a quick update to this review since I like to play this game before I go to bed. I mean I used to whatever they did for the latest update makes the entire game♥♥♥♥♥♥the bed when you hit the Mythic age. I'm talking lag so bad the entire game is literally unplayable. I swear if I didn't love this game so much as a kid.......

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												This game was fine for the most part. I sadly experienced a lot of lag because I only have 2GB RAM, while the recommended are 4GB RAM, but it didn´t make the game unplayable.The last two levels of the "Fall of the Trident" were very buggy. Even with a wall, the enemy still would go through it without destroying it, and after I won the last level, my screen went black and I was only able to go back to the Windows screen by shutting down computer by force.The cutscenes seem to go "underground", whenever a character has to be shown in a close up. Something that didn´t happen on the original game. All in all, while this game has the Titans expansion (which I never played) and improved graphics, it isn´t worth 30U$D + 10U$D for the DLC, maybe 20U$D for everything would have been better, considering also the reviews for the DLC.I enjoyed it, but I don´t fully recommend it.[EDIT, March 3 2016:] This game just isn´t even worth 8U$D. Bugs started accumulating since yesteday: 1) Relics which instead of having bonuses for units have god powers (Pestilence).2) My walls have the earthquake power.3) Black boxes which summed up the unit´s strength/weakness disappeared.4) Enemy units going through my walls without destroying them.5) Available god powers having a different name (E.G: Prosperity has the name of an Odin´s relic bonus).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Age of Mythology is a timeless RTS where players use their devotion and skill to ruin their enemies. It features a selection of Major Gods to choose from and then a series of Minor Gods to select as you advance through the ages, increasing the technologies and favour bestowed upon you. From humble beginnings with villagers struggling to gather food in the Archaic Age to armies of heroes, mythical creatures and human soldiers striding through vast empires in the Mythic Age, Ensemble Studios created a masterful entry into the 'Age of Empires' series that commands respect. Unfortunately, this rendition of the game is not the work of Ensemble Studios. In Age of Mythology: Extended Edition, the developers have criminally neglected it, this old masterwork riddled with connectivity issues and bugs that render it near-unplayable that weren't in the game before. The new Chinese civilisation, albeit well-designed mechanically, suffers from nearly all of its units being cheap re-textures of existing assets. If you can find a copy of the original game, there's an active community on there using a program to play online called "Voobly." So, if you wish to try Age of Mythology, that would be my recommendation. Try and cirvumvent this so-called "Extended Edition" if you can.In conclusion, this is a game many of us remember fondly. In the state it's currently in however, I'm sorry to say that it's better left alone until its current developers show it some more care.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												     tl;dr- Don't buy this game until the company that picked it up publicly apologizes for their bad buisness practices and actually fixes them.     Okay, this is coming from someone who owned AoMG back when it was still run by ESO. It was one of my favorite games, with tons of hours of content. It had a massive modding, and map making support and a huge number of people took advantage of this. I would always rebuy it because I wasn't paying 10$ for one game, I was paying 10$ for an infinite number. That praise isn't even mentioning the base game, with a large number of civilizations and different strategies for each. Age of Mythology Gold is an excellent game and I strongly recommend you pick it up.      The Extended Edition that steam sells is not. There has been a little bit of confusion as to who actually is running the servers and support for the Extended Edition, although the latter may be a bit of a misnomer as Age of Mythology Extended Edition is rife with errors, bugs, and inconsisntencies. There are a kalidescope of problems that can occur during a game session to cause it to crash, from disconnections (which effect a single person) to desync. For the most part the cult following on Steam has bore these burdens with resignation. They make jokes at the expense of the servers and MS Ryzon (Ex-Developer for The Extended Edition) is actually featured as a boss in one scenario. The bosses' talent? He cause lag and steals money.      We were however content to have a medium which we could play our game on once again even if this medium was buggier than an anteater's lunch infected with crabs. This changed with the recent release of the Tale of the Dragon DLC. For 10$, one could unlock the Chinese Civilization. The quality of this expansion is such, that MOST players believe it simply to be a monotized mod for the game, and a poorly done one at that. The mod plays like already existing civilizations and brings little unique to the table. What it does bring however, is a host of new errors to the game. Chat in pregame lobbies no longer work, desyncs have become far more common, and players are constantly reminded by game breaking pop-up ads to purchase the expansion pack every time a player of the Chinese Civilization does, well, anything.       The most serious problem however has appeared. Custom games no longer appear on the list of available games as they are constantly being "retreived". This has rendered the largest attraction to the AoM experience completely unplayable. When I went to report this error to the support page, I found it broken. The Support page. Purchasing DLC is still entirely functional but attempting to to get game fixing support is impossible due to a broken link. That's the real reason for this review.The reason the player base is so frustrated isn't the errors in the game, it's the complete contempt of the paying consumers that is ultimately driving players from this game. I've asked dozens of people in the base if they have a favorable opinion of the hoster of this game. Not one single person has a favorable opinion or at very least neutral opinion of this game's hoster. The real kicker? This game was hosted 10 years ago by Ensemble Studios Online (from the makers of Halo Wars) and ran much smoother then. A company that has since collapsed was objectively more sucessful than both Steam and Skybox when it comes to smoothly running this game.    SkyBox, if you're reading this. You need to apologize to the players of this game for bad support, bug fixes and a DLC that has only exacerbated the problem. AoM is not a difficult game to run, and it has a lot to offer to all bases. But if your inability to fix basic game errors keeps driving off old players, you'll end up with a game that has no replayablity whatsoever especially when compared to the new generation of turn-based strategy.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Age of Mythology has always been a great favourite of mine, wasted many thousands of hours on it (and in a good way) I even went as far to create a massive modification/overhaul of it called Expanded Mod for the Titans expansion.However Extended Edition is a very mixed bag, most of the time, the crappy work of the exe by Skybox Labs. and the code itself has caused many issues with lag, OOS etc overtime they have fixed this, but mostly because the small 1k community has coerced them into somewhat fixing it.  Rundown:PROS:+ All the Benefits of The Titans+ Four New Vanilla units (Patch 2.0 onwards) and 1 scenario editor/easter egg unit+ Addition of all extra-optional content by ES themself (Away from Home, +2 RMs, Golden Gift Campaign)+ Some Decent Balance+ Readdition of the Beta Ambient Lighting+ Improved Shadows (now dynamic, render based not .DCL/Texture files)+ Somewhat decent Mod Support, but... NEGS:- Crap Optimization, (run it with footprints + Amb Lights in 1024x768 should get around 45 FPS on most 2009 onwards Comps)- Nothing Spectacular content wise, if you know the Beta, AoE Twitch Livestreams, Alphas and Extra ES-made content.- Many Murky/Cloudy Textures, some texture stuff won't render correctly.- Eh Pathfinding- Still Needs a lot of fixing.- Lack of Dev Support- Almost no active communityYeah only 1k players play Online properly (even though there's 14k playing per 2 weeks, and only some 2-30 people playing non-private MP), even, also via the some 900,000+ purchases (roughly 27 million USD) Dev Support is really whack, so it's obvious that it's a money laundering scheme (MS is pretty infamous for that)Only get it, if your a non-Casual or below Age of Empires fan

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												After so many years the game has lost no charm, though it remains largely what it was before, except in one simple way, multiplayer. It adds a whole new challenge to the game, anyway, I aim this review at people who have never played the game before and are wondering "is it for me?"Firstly, a huge part of this game (so huge they put it in the title) is mythology, it has rich, historically accurate features that really add to the game, you can train myth units, and you can also wield God powers, (send lightning down on enemies, and even make an earthquake right in your enemies base.) Before you start a game you have to choose a Major God, such as Zeus, Thor, Loki and others (a total of 12) your major God will determine what units, God Powers, and upgrades you will have.Gameplay - This is a Real time strategy game, one of the very best, you start with a few villagers who can build and gather resources (wood, food, and gold.) There are four ages in which you must advance, the archaic age, the classical age, the heroic age, and finally the mythic age. As you advance through the ages you'll unlock new military units (infantry, archers, and cavalry), as well as myth units (minoutaurs, centaurs, cyclops and loads of others.) Ultimatley your goal is pretty simple... Beat the other guy. Advance faster, make bigger armies, or win in other ways such as building a wonder and defending for ten minutes. So it's quite a tactical game. You can also, right at the end of the final age, build a titan, it is like it sounds, a massive thing that tramples cities like godzilla.Graphics - they're perfectly fine, and nothing more. There is violence in the forms of armies battling it out for domination, but nothing very gorey, and there is no bad language, unless you count "Shkeepan" (you'll understand that joke if you play the game"This is a great game, it has a little bit of a learning curve but can be picked up pretty quick, the best part is that even after so many hours, you still have so much to learn, it provides hours of fun. A couple of down sides - Price: £22.99 is a lot for a game that is 10 years old, don't get me wrong, I've paid more for newer games that aren't as good, but I think it's a little steep. Online games can be a little tough to come by, perhaps if they had a sale then more players would realise the quality of this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
This is an honest review on Age of Mythology: Extended Edition.First off, a couple sentences about me so you know who this review is comming from.I started this game when I was 3 and my dad was playing it and he got me into it (it was escpecially fun because I am Greek and this helped me out in Mythology so when I went to 3rd grade in the Mythology class I literally knew everything even if some things arent 100% accurate to real mythology). I started the original version that came out in, I believe, 2001. Fast-forward a couple of years and I got the Titans version of the game bringing a whole newfaction (I will get into factions later). I lost the game when my old 9 year old laptop broke and I got it back some time ago when it went on a steam sale for 7 Euros. If the non-steam versions of the game tracked my hours aswell, I would easily have more than 1500.The main idea of the gameThe game is an RTS (Real time strategy), you get to command your villagers to gather resources, make your town, your army and even your navy and fight to the death with your enemies!You can choose in between 5 factions (Greek, Egyptian, Norse, Atlantean and Chinese)Every faction has 3 different "Main gods" (ex. Greeks have Zeus, Poseidon and Hades)Every faction and main god has a few different upsides and downsides. (ex. Hades has very good archers)There are 4 types of resources used to upgrade units,buildings and much more, Wood, Food, Gold and Favor (Favor is used to create mythical units like Minotaurs or get some God-Specific upgrades)You can also advance to different ages if you have the right resources( Archaic -> Classic -> etc (I typed this because I dont remember the names lol)When advancing to a new age you can select some "sub-gods" like Aphrodite or Hermes which all give different upgrades and myth units (ex. Athena gives Minotaurs) and ofcourse a god-power that is 1-use on most factions (ex. Ares gives the "pest" power which is used on enemy "unit-producing" buildings will make them unable to produce units for a short time.Those were the gameplay basicsThe current state of the game/communityThe game was created in 2001 as I said before. It was pretty succesful and a very fun RTS game.A few years later the "Titans" update came out (I believe this was around 2006).The titans update added some cool new features and a whole new faction, the Atlanteans!And after that. The game basically died. The developers company disbanded and the game and community was left in avery bad spot. Then at 2014 "Extended edition" came out on steam. It had its upsides and downsides. The majority of the community sticked to titans. That remained this way until 2015 where a new update came out. It added the Chinese faction and a whole new campaign with like 15 levels.The campaign was overall bad and all the myth units/gods felt really rushed and overpowered. The new designs for some myth units were litteraly other myth units recolored with a dragon head which spitted fire that could destroy any building in like 2 seconds. Very overpowered and not fun.That was for the "updates" part of the game. Now we will talk about the community which is basically dead. If you are on the game you will see that there are only like 25 people online at all times so its nearly impossible to get an online game unless you like to wait for like 3 hours or can convince some of your friends to get this game.The ratingsGraphics: 6.5 (For a very old game the graphics arent bad, but the bad graphics also have an upside of some sort since even lower end PC's can run it.)Campaign: 8/10 (The campaign is amazing to say the least. Personally for me it gave me nostalgia after playing it again after 8 years but if you are an RTS player you will definetly like the campaign)Community: 6/10 (The community at its current state isnt very good. The easiest way and probably the only way to play online currently is with friends,(The offline isnt very bad either tho, the bots especially on higher difficulties can  show a big challenge))Gamemodes: 8/10 (I would have combined gamemodes with the community but AoM is the type of game that you can literally make anything out of, a few examples: Roleplay, Settlers, a map of litterally THE WHOLE WORLD YOU CAN PLAY ON and much more)OVERALL RATING FOR AOM:EE : 7.5/10ConclusionIf you are an old player who played the titans version and possibly even the original you should give this game a try but maybe when its on a sale when its usually on 7 Euros.For new players seeing this game for the first time: If you are interested on this game you can read some more reviews or watch some youtube videos of it to get you to try it out, or if you have friends who are also interested in this game, get it on a sale if you have the money to spare and enjoy the game with your friends for guaranteed hours of fun! Good luck!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												A brilliant tribute to the original, the extended edition is a must-have for any RTS fan. Improvements such as steam integration and native multiplayer are as much fantastic additions as the recently enhanced lighting and graphics effects. With a simple tutorial for new players and three immersive campaigns, I intend on spending as many hours on this improved edition as I did on the original in my childhood. I would recommend this title to anyone interested in mythology because of the in-depth encyclopedia of classical history as well as anyone looking for a RTS with both a competitive and fun online multiplayer and single player options.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												This is a bit of a mixed bag here... Age of Mythology was one of the best, if not the best, real time strategy games of all time.  The expansion was incredible, and the extended edition adds some really cool stuff (the day/night cycle is beautiful!)  But to release a 12 year old game for $30 and not bother to fix bugs before releasing it?  The word scam comes to mind...  What possible explanation could there be for 'rushing' the re-release of a game from a dozen years ago?  If it were only Steam integration issues, it'd be less shameful, but things like memory leaks and texture issues should have fixed BEFORE charging anyone money for it.  I'd wait until they fix more bugs and it goes on sale for 75% off.  That said, if the thought of playing a modernized version of such a spectacular game is just too tempting to wait on, you won't be disappointed.  I haven't found the bugs to be too bad and the Steam Workshop is, as always, full of amazingness and growing quickly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												My playtime on steam doesn't even begin to touch the amount of playtime I ahve in this since I used to own the game on disk waaaay back in the day [I can probably still find it if I really tried too] But if you like RTS then you should absolutely get this- if you don't already have it. It's a fantastic game and one that even someone not super good at RTS can enjoy [IE: Me. I'm so bad I have to play everything on easy. Eventually I'll get better.] The campain is incredible in my opinion, I enjoy it immesily. It's a interesting way to make the player try every civilization- AND the story ain't awful if I'm being honest. I mean I didn't buy this game for the story, that was just a super awesome added bonus. I mean if you had to point out the flaws it may as well bethat yes the graphics are dated. It looks like it hasn't aged very gracefully, even with touched up graphics. Even so I find the graphics charming, they're simple enough to get the point across and they do that fairly well [I mean sometimes it's funny for a character to scream in a cutscene and their expression doesn't change. Maybe that's just me.] One of the only frustrating things is that the AI can be a bit buggy sometimes least in my efforts. Maybe I really do just suck at the game. And this is incredibly minor but those sayings that the units will yell when they're selected and moved do get old pretty fast. It's a minor complaint though, the game is still super worth it. [Be prepared to hear BUT before I let this get super long! Definitely get the game if you're a fan of RTS! Or Mythology! Or you really wanna check out something that's pretty darn fun. I love this game and I know I've rambled to my friends about it enough. I will add: I never played online. That seems to be another major complaint from people. As someone who does suck at the game I'm not thinking of trying it soon. But, everything outside that seems pretty awesome to me! 10/10 would recommend to all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7
												Age of Mythology has a tremendous amount of depth to it, and it would be  a shame for it to be down-rated due to poor graphics or other such novelties. The original developers really put a lot of thought into the economy, dynamics of civilizations, war play tactics, and ensuring that its consumers have the ability to run away with their imaginations in their map making sandbox. Many people tend to look over the small details that makes this game great, which is unfortunate. This game offers not only a  variety of extremely dynamic civilizations with varying god powers, strengths, and both passive/active procs such as priest that convert wild animals, buildings that when razed spawn militia, sky passages, and etc. But, it also provides great depth in the everyday game play. For example, ranged units generally have percent based accuricies that generally drop when against a moving target (which allows for great micro management in battles and a depth of skill and dynamic to warfare), cetain units have differents strengths and weaknesses, myth units come with a great varity of abilities that range from healing, to freezing, to acids spit, and the ability to eat trees or gold mines to heal oneself. There is also dynamic source of resources that vary with which the speed one can gather them and the amount they come in.And as I mentioned before, u have access to a map making sandboxes, and many players have created all types of scenerios such as SettlersZeldaNeo mutationBlood CastleRole Playing  MapsEscapeZonesand much more for different playing styles/modes.Now I have only touched the Iceburg, but I hope u get the chance to see the potential in the game, and the communities within it.
