number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												This is why I don't like Steam reviews; You can't have a middling opinion. Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is, at it's heart, the same good game we loved to play years ago. Pitting (mostly) real world civilizations with their own mythological flairs against each other to have a winner takes all brawl. Seeing cyclops throw men around like ragdolls or the villagers of an enemy die when you summon the cold horrors of Fimbulwinter will never get old. The problem is; The price and the DLC. I've heard MANY complaints over the multiplayer, but I don't play the multiplayer. Carrying on...The price of AoM: EE is far too much unless it's on sale. What (exactly) came into the brains of the people who fixed the price is beyond me. I can only assume someone fell asleep at the switch as this game should always be a cool $10 at most. Now onto the DLC; It reeks of mediocrity and is basically a fanmade piece, and not a particularly good fanmade one either. Look at the wonder that have been done with Wars of iberty for Age of Empires 3 to see what I mean; It's basically a small team of guys who poured themselves into research, polish, and creativity and came out with a winner. The guys who made Tales of the Dragon came up with a load of uninspired units and gardens, which are like many mini Vaults of Plenty (An end-game God power that nets you a trickle of resources; See how that can be overpowered)?The game itself is great, what they ask for it and what (new) things they've offered isn't. Don't get suckered in for full price, wait for a sale like I did.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												An RTS game where you get to lead armies supported by the creatures of Greek, Egyptian, and Norse Mythology? ♥♥♥♥ING SOLD.I did play the original version of this game... so many years ago. While it did not capture me quite like Age of Empires II did, AoM was still pretty good. In this remade version... well I don't really see any changes from the original, except for stuff like Steam support, being able to run on modern OS', and the usual stuff you see when an old game is remade for the present day. All important, of course, but for those who have already played AoM, there isn't really anything new here.As usual, I stuck to single-player since I'm a terrible online RTS player. The main campaign here drags on a bit long, but it is still plenty good and worthy of the Age RTS series. The expansions' campaigns, which I had never played until now, were also pretty neat in their own way. I still prefer AoE II's campaigns, but... nothing really beats those in my book. I am biased. XDUltimately, it's just good old RTS fun, except this time you can literally storm your enemies with Hydras, Anubites, or Valkyries instead of the usual hordes of spearmen, archers, and cavalry. Woohoo!Enjoy! :D

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												First of all, I've never played AoM or AoE or anything like this before, neither any strategy game like this. A friend of mine wanted to buy it and asked me if I wanted to share the four pack. I agreed and plled two more friends in... I loved playing Dota 2, but now, even when I miss racing around the map as Bloodseeker, I'm more willing to play AoM, because I loved it. I always play with a friend of mine, one of the two I pulled in, and he had already played it long eons ago, so he taught me the basics and we play cooperatively, almost like one civilization with two players... except our civilizations are never the same.For issues about connection, I admit there are some, but issues from Dota 2 are far worse than these, and mostly, I know it isn't the game's fault, but my friend's poor connection.The only real problem is... this game is just a ilttle expensive.... just the price to eat for a month... depending on how much you eat of course.So I suggest: put it on your wishlist and wait for steam's crazy discounts. The 4-pack we shared was for a bit more than $10.00 ... divided by four people. Plus, my share of the price was given as birthday gift.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												As far as I can tell, it feels like the original game patched to have mordern-ish graphics with a few bonuses. For those like me who have played the original and looked to this expecting something more refined, even if nothing new, you came to the wrong place! Most of the bugs in the original seem to still be around. I personally bought it to play with my friends online, but that is probably the most laughable thing there is. The application seems to use a client-side host with the steamworks intergration to connect players to eachothers servers. This alone isn't a bad thing, but the server seems so poorly optmized it feels that even the best of IPS will probably still have pretty bad lag. Simply put, steaming a YouTube video in HD is probably less taxing on your internet. Probably the worse part is the game has MEMORY LEAKS! Numerious times have myself and other players I know had there entire progress eradicated because of a memory allocation error which completely crashes the game. Rule of thumb in software development: critical bugs should not exist in finished products. Crashing to you desktop with a "Memory System Error" pop up is less than graceful and definitely counts as a critical bug.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												Good RTS, voice-acted campain taking place through the Greek, Egyptian, Scandinavian and Atlantean mythologies. While the extended edition does not bring many exciting things to the table, it at least allows to play in multiplayer. Must buy if on sale for 10$ or less. Should buy for any RTS player for the 20$ (somewhat expensive for what is essentially enabling multiplayer again for a classic).9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												As a kid, this was the first game I ever played. I would spend hours at a time playing it. When I saw that it was up on Steam, I was thrilled. I immediately bought it. The community is fairly small, but is close knit, and great maps are coming from the original AoM title back onto here. If you're on the fence about this game, take my word for it and by it. There are still some issues, but those are minor and you can hop right back into the game. The campaign is one of the best I have ever played, and creating your own game type/map is one of the best things that a video game can offer. Not only that, but you can gain info about the civilization that you are playing as AND get info on units like the minotaur, cyclops, and fire giants, just name a few. And what's NOT great about destroying your enemy with a bunch of giants spewing fire and ice?

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												I have played this game for a long time as you can see. This game is great and i love it. There are many, many problems with it though. The majority of the people on the game are terrible. There are so many bugs now, that its not even worth playing at this stage. You will desync the majority of the games, and the games that you don't will be quick. The only way to get a good game is to find friends that are at your skill level. To be honest, I only recommend this game to those who will take the time to deal with the bugs. Hopefully, the AOM team haven't given up on us, and are working to fix these bugs, but it doesn't really seem like they are. Good luck, and if you get the game, I hope you enjoy

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												I've played the game quite a bit, and never run in to any of the bugs everyone is talking about. I've played pre-made matches with real-life friends, matchmaking with random people, plenty of skirmishes against the AI, and the game has always held up just fine. Which is shocking, really, considering my laptop struggles to play most games, new or old. I've probably had fewer issues playing AoM than any other game. Which is just to say that the "game-breaking" bugs are not as widespread as some of the negative reviews may lead you to believe.It's a fun classic-style RTS with an interesting theme, plenty of faction/sub-faction variety, and the kind of easy-to-learn hard-to-master strategic-depth you'd expect out of a good strategy game. A solid 9/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												A classic of the RTS genre, Age of Mythology greatly played to my love of the Greek and Egyptian Mythologies and introduced me to the Norse. Mind you this was back when AoM was first released back in 2002. I loved it then and I loved it now.The game plays like your standard Age of Empires styled RTS game. Gather resources, build an army, topple your enemies. This game introduces a unique resource known as Favor which is generated differently across the 4 factions of the game. The Greeks require villagers to worship at the temple, Egyptians build up to 5 monuments, the Norse gain favor through battle, and the Atlantians gain favor by controling Town Centers. Favor can be spent to purchase specific god related upgrades or train myth units which can give you an edge. Each facton can, technically, be broken down into three subfactions divided up by the major god the faction uses. Greeks can worship Zeus, Hades, or Posedeon, Egyptians worship Ra, Isis, or Set, Norse worship Thor, Odin, or Loki, and the Atlantians worship Kronos, Oranos, or Gaia. Each major god carries their own unique god powers and other benefits upon their faction. For instance, following Thor grants you access to a Dwarven Gold Mine which, depending on the age in which it is used, acts as a free bonus Gold Mine for players to use. Similarly Thor allows for the construction of a Dwarven Armory which researches cheaper upgrades than average armories. Each major god also has a select list of minor gods for you to choose from when advancing from one age to the next. You can only pick one of two gods to worship and will gain the benefits from that god once you reach the next age. Each minor god grants you a special myth unit to use and each myth unit has its own unique traits. For example the Egyptian Scarab is a living siege unit designed to destroy enemy structures, the Greek Pegasus is a flying scout, etc. Each of the minor gods includes unique upgrades that can be researched that affect specific groups like cavalry, villagers, infantry, etc.The god powers for each faction also differs. The Atlantians have a slight advantage with their god powers as some of them carry multiple charges and can be used more than once after a cooldown period. Up to 4 god powers can be acquired at a time, with your initial power coming from your major god and three subsiquent powers being gained from the minor gods.In addition to basic units, there are also hero units. Hero units are the counter to myth units as they're meant for just that purpose of eliminiating the myth units. Each faction has their own hero units. Egyptians have Priests and the Pharoh, Norse have a hammer wielding melee hero, and Atlantians can promote any one of their infantry or cavalry units into heroes for a price. Greeks seem to have the short end as they only get up to 4 heroes at a time and these heroes may vary between infantry, cavalry, or archer. However the Greek Heroes have their own unique abilities such as Ajax being able to bash enemy units away with his large shield.And then there are the Titans! The Titans were introduced with the Titans expansion and AoM is probably one of the first games to introduce a game changing uber-unit. Upon reaching the mythic age, each faction can place a Titan Gate which, once it is uncovered/constructed by the faction's builder units, releases a Titan which is a massive and powerful melee unit that deals unbelievable damage and in most cases can obliterate an entire army singlehandedly. The only drawback to the Titans are that their health is finite and any health lost is lost forever and if the Titan dies, you don't get another one. The most effective counter to a Titan is another Titan or a host of ranged hero units. The Atlantians seem to have a slight advantage here as if the minor goddess Hecate is worshiped, a special bonus of hers allows all myth units to gradually regenerate their health, and Titans are concidered myth units.The only real drawback to the game is that you're fixed to only one camera angle with a top down view. This is from 2002 so that can be forgiven as a "dated mechanic." Your army size is limited to 200 population points max and most units take up at least two or more population points so you're not going to have armies numbering in the thousands. You'll be lucky to have an army in the dozens. Villagers also count against the population cap. Another frustration with the population cap is that population is determined by the number of houses or town centers you have. Greeks, Egyptians, and Norse can build up to 10 houses to increase their population while Atlantians can build up to 5 Manors which offer the same benefit but can also be garrisoned by other units for defense. After that, the only way to increase your unit cap is to build additional town centers and those can only be built on top of pre-existing settlements in the world and those settlements may or may not be in an optimal position. You could easily find an availible perilously close to your enemy's camp. If the map has a water feature such as a large lake or a chain of islands that isolate you from your enemy, be ready to use up half of your population to building naval defenses as ships count against the population count too. And don't bother summoning your titan from the safey of your base if you're on an island because then it becomes a glorified watchdog as Titans cannot board transports and cannot go across the water. They're landlocked so if you use up that titan gate, you're stuck with a titan at your base. Great for defense if the enemy makes it to shore (No ranged attack on the Titan, remember) but besides that...Also be very careful on where you use your titan gate power because if you demolish it by accident or it gets destroyed by your enemy, you don't get it back and its gone forever along with all chances of your getting a titan, especially if you've got one baring down on your base.Still, Age of Mythology is an RTS that should be played by every RTS fan.There is also an interesting piece of news. Age of Mythology may very well be the first game ever to recieve an expansion pack update for the first time since the last official update 13 years after the game was released. The Tale of the Dragon Expansion Pack is supposed to include an all new faction: The Chinese and include figures and deities from Chinese mythology. The expansion pack is set to be released on January 28th of this year. And just to give you some perspective, The original Age of Mythology was released in 2002 with the Titans Expansion releasing the year after in 2003. Now we're getting an expansion pack in 2016. That's almost 14 years after the game came out. For a game to be this old and recieve an update like this 14 years later is definately something worth noting.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												I have been playing this game since it came out in 2002 and I was just a little girl.  This is definitely a classic game and is great for all ages.  The game is a great strategy multiplayer starter.  The single player is also fun to do.  I highly recommend this game for everyone from young to old.Pros: Easy to learn with tutorial and campaign mode.  Fun multiplayer that is customizable.  Twitch ready.  Nice sound effects and music.Cons: Old graphics -- so don't expect 4kUHD when playing this game.-mahalz143sinta-

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Sadly, this relaunch of an old success is a complete waste of money. Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is suffering with a lot of problems and neither Microsoft Studios or SkyBox Labs seems to really worry about their reputation.Considering that the multiplayer isn't working really well after more than a whole year since the release date, there's no good reasons to recommend it. It's a real let down for the old fans.For new players, i suggest a smarter deal: buy the original version of the game, even without any kind of technical support.

You'll be lucky to have an army in the dozens. Villagers also count against the population cap. Another frustration with the population cap is that population is determined by the number of houses or town centers you have. Greeks, Egyptians, and Norse can build up to 10 houses to increase their population while Atlantians can build up to 5 Manors which offer the same benefit but can also be garrisoned by other units for defense. After that, the only way to increase your unit cap is to build additional town centers and those can only be built on top of pre-existing settlements in the world and those settlements may or may not be in an optimal position. You could easily find an availible perilously close to your enemy's camp. If the map has a water feature such as a large lake or a chain of islands that isolate you from your enemy, be ready to use up half of your population to building naval defenses as ships count against the population count too. And don't bother summoning your titan from the safey of your base if you're on an island because then it becomes a glorified watchdog as Titans cannot board transports and cannot go across the water. They're landlocked so if you use up that titan gate, you're stuck with a titan at your base. Great for defense if the enemy makes it to shore (No ranged attack on the Titan, remember) but besides that...Also be very careful on where you use your titan gate power because if you demolish it by accident or it gets destroyed by your enemy, you don't get it back and its gone forever along with all chances of your getting a titan, especially if you've got one baring down on your base.Still, Age of Mythology is an RTS that should be played by every RTS fan.There is also an interesting piece of news. Age of Mythology may very well be the first game ever to recieve an expansion pack update for the first time since the last official update 13 years after the game was released. The Tale of the Dragon Expansion Pack is supposed to include an all new faction: The Chinese and include figures and deities from Chinese mythology. The expansion pack is set to be released on January 28th of this year. And just to give you some perspective, The original Age of Mythology was released in 2002 with the Titans Expansion releasing the year after in 2003. Now we're getting an expansion pack in 2016. That's almost 14 years after the game came out. For a game to be this old and recieve an update like this 14 years later is definately something worth noting.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Mmm~ if you played this years back and wanted to do so on modern systems today like I did, this doesn't disappoint.  Basically the same delectable game (and one of my favorite RTS games of all time) as it was back then, with a few bugs in transition, but largely nothing game breaking, since last I remember they fixed the Steamworks issues I had with inviting my friend.For nostalgia buyers, you're going to get exactly what you think you're getting.  My only complaint is the rather high price tag for literally the same, old game, but eh, whatever.  Perhaps some of the magic is lost from when I played this as one of my first "actual" computer games when I was younger, but it all still holds up, and I can now appreciate the competitive and game design side of things, even if I am too chicken to play matchmaking.For newcomers, I like to think the game has a very welcoming feel.  The art style is appropriate and iconic, the units are unique and every one of them has unique voice lines and voice effects, and the music is some of the best ambient tracks I know of.  Units respond snappily and intelligently, the interface is clean and streamlined, and I can't think of a single gripe with the resource management and building.  Er, well, the walls are sometimes a bit annoying to construct, but I rarely used those.The game also comes with a concise and bite-size encyclopedia (accessible at any given time - even in game) of all of the gods and units included in the game and their usage and role in their given society, which is actually fascinating to read and largely attributed to my modest knowledge of the mythologies today.  Overall, I have no regrets buying the same game at a probably higher price than I got it before.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Age of Mythology is venerable and is showing it's age. Even with the updated graphics and newly added effects, the core gameplay is still fairly simple. Newer titles offer a richer diversity of tactics and options. AoM is interesting to play for it's original variety and to see how strategy games have developed from this stage, but other than that it unfortunately doesn't offer much more.This is not to say it's a bad game, after all comparing it to newer titles who have the developments and ideas to proceed from the mistakes of their precursors is hardly fair.AoM is still a great deal of fun to play. The newly created campaign is fairly interesting, the integration of Steamworks for easy download of new scenarios and UI updates is very welcome, as well as the sharing of old scenarios (more on this in a bit).The problem is it lags terribly at times, and rather randomly so; the loading times, particularly post-game tend to drag out which seems ridiculous considering I used to run this on an old Pentium 2, but even with quad core and graphics cards on a modern system it still lags? This is rather disappointing and something is not quite right with the graphical overhaul. The steam edition also removed all scenarios, so even some of the standard edition ones that came with the DVD edition of the game are not included, luckily Steamworks has countered this, but it's still frustrating that SkyBox Labs decided to remove previous content that should have been included in the initial install especially considering that they are still charging a fairly high price for the game.Despite the uncomfortable problems, AoM: EE still boasts longevity through multiplayer and the campaign editor for creation of new content.It is worthwhile to play for those who want a blast of nostalgia, or even those who are just curious to see how far RTS strategy titles have progressed.I recommend the following Map Packs from Steamworks to subscribe to:Map Pack  by Bobba<3 Simon4lifeMenirz's collection of Ensemble Era Map Packs

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												First of all I should mention that I'm not reviewing the original game which remains to this day a superb game, one of my childhood's favourites. The so called 'Extended edition', however, is a mess. The new chinese cultures bring nothing new to the game, and are completely bleak compared to the original three/four. The thing that bothers me the most, however, is the port itself. The extended edition was supposed to have improved graphics, but you can hardly spot it. The only thing that tweaks in the game's engine have caused is the unbelievable lag and stuttering even on machines that can run most of the contemporary games. Honestly, for a port of a 2002 game this is unacceptable. I haven't really tried to play the game online, but since the experience in the single player mode was already so cringy, I don't really expect the game to be playable online at all - I've read some of the other reviews, and apparently that's exactly the case. Overall, I'd only suggest you to buy the game if you find it on sale and just in case you cannot possibly find the original game anywhere. As said before, the graphical 'improvements' are barely noticable and the lag they cause ruins the whole experience. The chinese cultures don't bring anything significant to the game, so the game is definetely not worth the whole price.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Review for Tale of the Dragon.Would i recommend this expansion to anybody to buy? No i bloody would not. I bought it on sale and i STILL feel short-changed! The campaign is boring as hell and even if i did enjoy it i would say it is too short anyway. The expansion is buggy as hell and it has been out for a while already! Villagers getting stuck between berry bushes, villagers standing there and not delivering the resource they have gathered. Heroes not reviving, heroes reviving and then just hovering about not attacking. Units getting stuck magically on terrain like cliffs, going up there somehow (even though there was no path available) and then not being able to magically make their way back down. Graphical glitches where buildings kinda 'flicker'. The god powers are also boring as hell and i dont think i found even one that i enjoyed that much. Maybe Steam should change things so in certain circumstances one can get their money back after being completely disappointed when having completed a game or expansion. I know that sounds a bit silly and extreme but thats the way i feel about this steaming pile of nonsense.So again, would i recommend anybody buying this expansion? Heck no. Save your money and spend it on something more worthy (shouldnt be too hard to find). Go and play it for free somehow ;) Like at a mates house or something :PStay away from this expansion unless you are extremely and easily impressed.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Dodgy and unncessessary recreation of the original. The online support is pathetic, with a game which was previously capable of running on a dial-up internet connection, now incapable of running on a broadband connection without intense lag which only increases with each additional player. Pathfinding is far worse, meaning that often you have to navigate units manually around obstacles. Sounds appear to either not play or be missing in some cases, leaving a massive tornado totally silent while the music merrily hums along in the background. In some places graphics have been rendered worse than how they originally appear, farms seem de-saturated and fish have a bizarre pixelation in the ocean.When playing with a group of friends against bots (the lag was intoloerable, a player on my own network was also lagging as well as myself - the player who started the game), we had the same colour green used for both a member of our team and the enemy team. This lead to a lot of confusion.To summarize, just don't buy it.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												This is a great game for the old school strategy games lovers and especially those that used to play the original Age of Mythology and want to relive their childhood. However there have been some issues that force me to not recommend this game.The good The game is what it calls itself. It's the classic Age of Mythology with improved visuals, which to me are a welcome change Golden gift campain. I never had the chance to play this campain, nor was I aware of it's existance, so it was a fun bonus The game supports the workshopThe bad  There has been an issue to A LOT (including me) users where the game doesn't launch at all (redownloading, verifying integrity of game cache doesn't seem to work) Multiplayer can be very laggy, making it super annoying to play with your friends You are basically paying for the old Age of Mythology with some make-up onValue for moneyAssuming you won't have an issue with running the game, it is still fairly expensive (Standing on 27.99€) for just a re-skin. If you could find it being on a 50% sale, you could consider getting it. 75-80% sale is totally worth it Final thoughts If I were you I would not buy Age of mythology: Extended Edition as long as the issue of the game not starting still exists

content:

												I was a huge fan of the original version of this game and I was excited for a chance to own it again and play it with my friends, even at the rather absurd price for this thing. Unfortunately, 90% of the time, it's completely unplayable. This is the worst lag I have ever experienced in a steam game, up to 15-20 seconds per in game second with little to no letting up. This experience is universal among all my friends who I got this game with, regardless of who they're playing or where they are. If you're looking at getting it, I recommend Age of Empires instead, despite the buggy and incompetent AI if you're looking to play this with anyone else. I don't recommend buying this before it's fixed, though this has been brought up so many times since it's been released, I doubt it will be.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												EDIT: I literally just finished writing this review and then saw the RPS link that they're announcing a new expansion on chinese mythology. At the moment I still hold my stance on the game, But I will re-pick it up when the expansion comes out and change my review accordingly.As a long time fan of both Age of Empires and Age of Mythology, I'm going to say that unless you have an extreme attachment to Age of Mythology, go with the HD Remake of Age of Empires II for now. I'm writing this on the 2015/2016 christmas season, so maybe in the future this review will become outdated, but at the time of writing there is little support for this game compared to the other HD Remake of the same series.Firstly, Age of Empires has gotten 2 DLC packs that are both great. Expansions and improvements to a 15+ year old game. Rebalances and slight tweaks all the way to adding brand new techs to change the viability of certain kinds of play. I'm not expecting Age of Mythology to get anywhere near adding new expansions to the game as Age of Mythology is a much more advanced and complicated game with more going on, which takes quite a lot more time and materials to get it running- but the fact of the matter is that Age of Mythology EX hasn't gotten nearly any updates that mean anything since it has come out, in both gameplay aspects and technical aspects. Age of Empires II HD was extremely laggy in online and broken in multiple ways when it first came out, and so was Age of Mythology EX. The difference is that Age of Empires II HD actually fixed most of it's problems through patches, while Age of Mythology EX still chugs on some systems by managing to run worse than the original game even with lower graphical settings and online is still a buggy mess. There are apparently memory leaks within the game too, which make it slowly stutter as the game goes on, especially when the unit cap increases too.This isn't really an offensively bad port, otherwise. I can't really say I am downright angry with this upgrade to steam, actually I'm kind of glad it happened so I can at least play half of a match (before it randomly disconnects) with friends again without having to go through confusing game channels. The game is still the same as before, nothing awful has changed... If you don't like the Day/Night cycles you can turn them off as far as I remember, and the updated water gets turned back closer to what it was like in the original if you have you graphics turned down low enough (at least from my testing). Overall, I am still going to play this game and enjoy it, and if you're a huge fan of this game you will enjoy it too- but if you're just considering this or another Age of XXXX game, AoE2HD is a much, much better upgrade currently and will not eviscerate your system if you're running something mildly old.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												This is the third time I've purchased this game.AOM is my favourite in the "age of" series by a large amount. While an old game now I still have fun jumping on it here and there and having a few games with friends of against the AI. For people who have yet to play this game, don't be put off by the mythological theme. This is still a great game that will give you the same satisfaction that you have gotten from the other titles. The campaign is fun and quite a lengthy investment. The expansion added campaign following the original is fantastic as well. You can live without the dwarves focused one, while it has some fun ideas for maps it's short, easy and lacks any real depth . The main problem I had with these in the newest steam version was that the graphical quality seems to have been dramatically reduced. I played the old version less than six months ago on a ten year old laptop and it looked better than this version on my new $3k rig. The day and night cycle is over rated and really serves no point, if anything I found it broke the game up more and turned it off. Multiplayer is fun but expect to play against strong players. Random AI matches are the same as before but with two new game types. They can be fun but I've always been a conquest or occasionally supremacy fan. Overall it's basically the same game that it was in the past. The steam community seems to have produced a nice array of new mods to enjoy and I've had fun revisiting this game once again. If you are considering repurchasing this game, wait for a sale and pick it up cheap, it's the same game. If you are looking at this game for the first time and enjoy similar games in the "age of" series you should enjoy this title and get your money's worth from it but it may seem a little dated at first. 7/10

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												This is an old RTS game from 2002I usually refrain from buying  old games that were released before 2007 as  most have been a terrible disapointment. Even though the graphics look old, outdated and haven't been improved much at all, the game is ok to play. I find the game mostly enjoyable to play even though it is an ugly game with graphics from 2000. And with AOM  Extended Edition, doesn't seem like much  has been added or changed/improved. It says improved graphics, but it doesn't look like it, all that seems to have improved is a bit of water texture, shadow and some lighting and it's still ugly old outdated textures. I like how there is a mythological aspect to the game, it makes it more interesting for me, to choose a god and have various powers you can evoke, though rather limited, powers such as call down a bolt of lightning to instant kill a enemy. And a devastating meteor that will destroy a small area. These powers are very limited though, only being able to use once per map, so should be used wisely.I also like that there are heroes and myth units, creatures like minotaurs and hydra that become stronger and grow another head after a kill.I get bored playing too much, usually after a couple of hours, as all it is, is fighting and nothing much else. And I feel happy when I complete a campaign scenario and then feel disapointed that there's another one to complete. So I probably don't like the campaign game much as it drags on and on. The campaign takes way too long to complete, usually I like lengthy games, but not when the story involved is rather boring and the scenario missions don't differ much as every one is mostly just build your base up, build army, attack and defeat. I just want it to hurry up and be over already. The campaign should be 15 to 20 scenarios at most, not 32. I prefer to play just random maps in short bursts.And it's frustrating when you get halfway through a scenario, only to have the game crash and you try and reload a recent save but the save file is stuffed and wont load so have to start the scenario from the begining again.I liked the game over all and say it's worth getting and playing at a discounted price for $10 or less, but not for full price as it's just an old rehashed game which has outdated graphics and not many improvements. Nothing that modernises or makes it feel worthy of the so called Extended title.6/10 ok.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												If you're looking for a RTS single player experience, this game is good for you, if you're looking for a RTS to play with anyone that isn’t on fiber internet speeds, do not buy this game. This game instead of using dedicated servers uses a peer to peer system in which if a single person is lagging (due to a moderate or slow internet connection) the entire game for everyone will lag.Overall, this is a disappointment especially since the original game worked on dial-up speeds. Therefore I would not recommend buying this game.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is the enhanced version of the classic RTS game Age of Mythology (2002). It plays a lot like Age of Empires series, but with the use of god powers (spells alike), mythycal units and the controversial Titan, an extremely OP unit used to crush entire armies.Those accustomed to Age of Empires II (like me) will have to develop new strategies. Rushing and spamming units is a lot less efficient in AoM, because you can't build a lot of houses before claim new settlements (town centers) and the power of gods adds spicy situations that can turn the table in a favor of a player. Also, AoM has a lot less nations, but they're extremely different and will take you a lot of matchs to master them.The Extended Edition has graphics improvements, HD support, new online features (like the observer mode and Twitch integration) and steamworks features, like the Workshop, where you can download new maps, texture packs, etc. It comes with the Titans expansion (2003) and the extra official campaign "Golden Gift". To beat all campaigns it will take 20+ hours. There's a lot of map types and game modes to play in Skirmish and Multiplayer. The replay value is high enough to keep you hooked for a long, long time.IMO, some things needs to be addressed, like the mediocre pathing and some MP issues with players from different countries (if you play with someone near to you, the match will be smooth). While I enjoy this game a lot, I think it's a bit pricey for a 10+ years game with minor improvements. Thankfully, AoM: EE receives great discounts from time to time. Wait for a sale and join the community!

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												The Tale of the Dragon is a terrible expansion to our beloved Age of Mythology's franchise! The Chinese's civilizations are unfairly balance against the other civilizations in the game. 50+ scout cavalry with low HP but high damage is an equivalent to to the Egyptian's Mercenary cavalry. Even though they have high HP, they have limited time to live unlike the Chinese's scout cavalry! And don't get me started on the vermillion birds, this things is so OP that it's just ruin the game!Even the Chinese's god powers are unfairly unbalanced, that's make the Atlantean's God Powers looks like a vanilla!But the online game is really fun, the community are tight knit and friendly! There's unlimited scenario to play with and you can hone your skills against the players around the worlds. You can even team up with them and take on Titan AIs that you find it difficult to do on single player.Over all, the expansion was terrible but thanks to Forgotten Empire for releasing this game on Steam for the fan to play and battle online as well as Ensemble Studio for being the original creator and master of the franchise. Have fun!O CANADA WUV WUV WOO PANDORAS BOX

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												Age of Mythology is one of the RTS games that everyone who could use a computer in the early 2000's has played. It is an undeniable classic. All the more reason to give it a new paintjob for the next decade. Skybox has been busy bringing most of Microsoft's classic strategy names to the high definintion screen. A graphical tough up here, some upscaling there, a new netcode, steam intergration, and some more funny stuff, but when you compare it to the original version, you're going to be dissapointed. I still own the disk for Age of Mythology and it runs like a purring kitten on my laptop. This updated HD version...barely any improvement. It is still very much the same game. Basically the devs went to the game and replaced its parts with modern, more durable ones. Kinda like going into a house and replacing all the lightbulbs with LEDs and replacing the TV with flatscreen. It is superficial, and it doesn't even come close to justify its outrageous pricepoint. The game itself is still stiff, the voice acting weird and many of units that look impressive lack the punch you'd expect. What skybox has done is put new wheels and paint on a classic hot rod old it as new while the ride has gotten awful over the years and tires spin out when you try to pull away.

content:
Posted: January 1
												The original AoM from ye olde disk is fantastic and one of my favorite games of all time. This port, however, is not. It claims to be an "extended" or "enhanced," but manages to look and play worse than the original. I was incredibly excited for the expansion, but was again let down by extensive balance issues that took days or even weeks to fully fix and that a complete newcomer to the game could have diagnosed within their first match. The only redeeming features of this game are that Steam integration makes multiplayer way easier than mucking through Gameranger or Hamachi LAN emulators, and that it runs on Windows 10 (The original version with Safedisk no longer functions on my clean installation of Windows). While this game is absolutely worth playing, try to get the original version to work instead of the Steam version if possible. Although I cannot recommend this game in good conscience, I will continue to play it for the forseeable future as a (barely) functional substitute.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Here we are again with another of Ensemble's games.  Ensemble, in case you're wondering, is an old PC dev that published under microsoft then went bankrupt.  This game?  I've heard good things about it.  Will I ever know if it's good or not?  No.  Why?  Well, this isn't actually the game we knew.  It's a copy-and-paste remake by Skybox Labs, but one part was changed [for the worse]-- the netcode.Its netcode is ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Let me just tell you about ONE match, one that was in LAN... 17 out of sync errors, an army that recognizes orders up to 2 seconds later than you clicked, a screen that only renders enemy armies on the minimap, but doesn't show you the actual army until 5 seconds after they've supposedly come close enough to see, in which they lag-teleport forward.I don't know why I trusted these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s at Skybox a second time.  This is the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t they pulled with Age of Empires 2 "HD Edition," a fake HD edition (looked just as old as classic, textures that were changed I changed back because they looked like♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a terrible netcode as well.  This time, perhaps they didn't sell off somebody's modwork as paid DLC, but it's still just as unplayable as AoE2.Do not recommend under any circumstances.  Final verdict: Go buy it on disc from Amazon for around $8, new condition.  The original game's only from 2007, so compatibility issues are only a problem on Windows 8 in which case some have fixed it and I'm sure there are directions to fixing the game for Win8.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												Age of Mythology is a game of heroes and monsters, mighty armies and epic deeds. Lead your culture through the ages, from humble beginnings in a small village, to mighty citadels protected by the power of the Gods. Tear down the walls of Troy, battle Giants in the frozen wastes near Midgard and fight armies of Anubites in the shifting sands of Egypt.The Gods, as a token of appreciation, may someday reward you with great Earth-changing powers in Age of MythologyEh, what more can I say? Its a very good Age of Empires game with a bit of Mythology. Singleplayer is amazing, filled with memorable story, action, characters and very unique levels. It also have hight replayability, with 4 different difficulty settings.Multiplayer is great (a bit of connection issues but its still active).The game works perfectly fine like in old days with addition of improved visuals,  modern resolution support and few balance changes. The game have also build in interesting encyclopedia about many things, both history and mythology.Age of Mythology: Extended Edition have a lot of content that will keep RTS fans for many hours.

												The Tale of the Dragon is a terrible expansion to our beloved Age of Mythology's franchise! The Chinese's civilizations are unfairly balance against the other civilizations in the game. 50+ scout cavalry with low HP but high damage is an equivalent to to the Egyptian's Mercenary cavalry. Even though they have high HP, they have limited time to live unlike the Chinese's scout cavalry! And don't get me started on the vermillion birds, this things is so OP that it's just ruin the game!Even the Chinese's god powers are unfairly unbalanced, that's make the Atlantean's God Powers looks like a vanilla!But the online game is really fun, the community are tight knit and friendly! There's unlimited scenario to play with and you can hone your skills against the players around the worlds. You can even team up with them and take on Titan AIs that you find it difficult to do on single player.Over all, the expansion was terrible but thanks to Forgotten Empire for releasing this game on Steam for the fan to play and battle online as well as Ensemble Studio for being the original creator and master of the franchise. Have fun!O CANADA WUV WUV WOO PANDORAS BOX

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												Remember the days of old, the age of glory for Age of Empires and The Settlers? Well, that's where Age of Mythology comes in.One has to admit that 9 out of 10 purchases of this Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is made purely for nostalgic reasons. Most buyers remember this game from the past, or from their childhood, and are glad it's got a reboot, escpecially after Microsoft completely removed the ESO (online Multiplayer) support for Age of Mythology, making the game only playable through LAN and VPNs. For those people it's more than obvious that the game's a viable purchase.Mind that Age of Mythology is highly educational. It's an RTS that uses 4 different kinds of mythological cultures as factions to fight each other. You can choose Norse, Greek, Egyptian and "Atlantean" gods to worship, in which the atlanteans tend to worship Greek titans rather than gods. The upgrades, units, myth creatures and buildings are extremely and surprisingly accurate to what is described in their respective mythologies, and the game even has a built-in encyclopedia full of lore behind each entity and upgrade within the game. Before actually having proper mythological history classes, Age of Mythology was my base mythological knowledge and by the dragons, it gave me a huge advantage. Age of Mythology is definitely an entertaining way to learn about ancient culture and old religions.Are you looking for something shiny and revolutionary? Look elsewhere. This game is quite old and despite the updates, it hasn't got the fancy graphics and mechanics you'd get in strategy games nowadays. Are you into retro-ish games with stable mechanics and decent online gameplay? Yes, this will work out fine.There's some issues I have with this game, though. First of all, the game is expensive, considering that the only real addition to the classic game that is truly significant is the reboot of the online game mode. The game has the same old bugs and the game's connection online is worse than it's been in the old days. But... I guess it works, which is quite an improvement. The issue is more or less that it is very much questionable whether matches of the day, online support, achievements and minor tweaks (which are mostly imported scripts that one could've just downloaded from AoM Heaven or whatever Age of Mythology fan website) such as changing of seasons and "updated graphics" (which are barely notable) are actually worth the money. If you're extremely interested in and devoted to the comeback of random PvP online gameplay within Age of Mythology, then yes, consider getting this. If you're up for amazing new features and fixes to the game other than ranked online modes, I do NOT recommend this, for the new features are barely notable and not worth your money.Why do I recommend this game? Because I'm rating Age of Mythology here, and not the extended edition per se. The game is not bad, the game is actually quite fantastic. It's the extended edition updates that's just not worth the effort in my opinion. In conclusion, Age of Mythology is an all-time classic and must-have for those who enjoyed Age of Empires and other relatively old RTS games. The rules of thumb for purchasing this game are:- IF you're extremely interested in random PvP online Age of Mythology gaming, buy the extended edition. Note that the connection is bad and you will experience a lot of lag.- IF you are a fan of Age of Mythology and want to support the reboot, regardless of the additions being underwhelming, buy the extended edition.- IF you're here for revolutionary RTS experiences and shiny new mechanics, move along.- IF you're not interested in history and mythology, move along.- IF you don't care about the online mode and/or find the additions not impressive, get an old copy of Age of Mythology + the Titans expansion at your game store or online. You can get these old copies for about $2 and they run perfectly fine on ANY XP or higher Windows OS without trouble, and the LAN feature will work fine, so if you want to play with some known friends you can just use a VPN client like Hamachi or Evolve.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Dont get fooled by the positive rates, this game is nothing but a big disappointment and the same story as the remake of Age of Empires II "HD". Someone who rates this game positive is making a giant mistake. People actually think of the original game, which came out in the early 2000' and not the so called "Extended Edition" which is now available on Steam. If people were held to rate only the "new" EE, all the thumbs would go down. Dont get me wrong, the original AoM aswell as AoE II were briliant games which i truly admire. Publishers take an old and sucessful game, dont change anything at all and call it afterwards "HD" or "Extended Edition" to resell it for 10-30€The graphics are the same like in the original game, the resolution of 1920x1080 doesnt fit to the rest of the game.The multiplayer is a complete mess with tons of bugs, crashes, laggs, etc.. It takes forever to start a game cause you cant find other players online and if you get a game finally started, you got 50% chance that you, or anyone else drops or crashes and disc.The game is in no case worth its price of around 30,00€. My recommendation is to get this game on sales for a max. price of 5-8€ or find the original one and install it again.

content:
Posted: January 1
												The original AoM from ye olde disk is fantastic and one of my favorite games of all time. This port, however, is not. It claims to be an "extended" or "enhanced," but manages to look and play worse than the original. I was incredibly excited for the expansion, but was again let down by extensive balance issues that took days or even weeks to fully fix and that a complete newcomer to the game could have diagnosed within their first match. The only redeeming features of this game are that Steam integration makes multiplayer way easier than mucking through Gameranger or Hamachi LAN emulators, and that it runs on Windows 10 (The original version with Safedisk no longer functions on my clean installation of Windows). While this game is absolutely worth playing, try to get the original version to work instead of the Steam version if possible. Although I cannot recommend this game in good conscience, I will continue to play it for the forseeable future as a (barely) functional substitute.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												Remember the days of old, the age of glory for Age of Empires and The Settlers? Well, that's where Age of Mythology comes in.One has to admit that 9 out of 10 purchases of this Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is made purely for nostalgic reasons. Most buyers remember this game from the past, or from their childhood, and are glad it's got a reboot, escpecially after Microsoft completely removed the ESO (online Multiplayer) support for Age of Mythology, making the game only playable through LAN and VPNs. For those people it's more than obvious that the game's a viable purchase.Mind that Age of Mythology is highly educational. It's an RTS that uses 4 different kinds of mythological cultures as factions to fight each other. You can choose Norse, Greek, Egyptian and "Atlantean" gods to worship, in which the atlanteans tend to worship Greek titans rather than gods. The upgrades, units, myth creatures and buildings are extremely and surprisingly accurate to what is described in their respective mythologies, and the game even has a built-in encyclopedia full of lore behind each entity and upgrade within the game. Before actually having proper mythological history classes, Age of Mythology was my base mythological knowledge and by the dragons, it gave me a huge advantage. Age of Mythology is definitely an entertaining way to learn about ancient culture and old religions.Are you looking for something shiny and revolutionary? Look elsewhere. This game is quite old and despite the updates, it hasn't got the fancy graphics and mechanics you'd get in strategy games nowadays. Are you into retro-ish games with stable mechanics and decent online gameplay? Yes, this will work out fine.There's some issues I have with this game, though. First of all, the game is expensive, considering that the only real addition to the classic game that is truly significant is the reboot of the online game mode. The game has the same old bugs and the game's connection online is worse than it's been in the old days. But... I guess it works, which is quite an improvement. The issue is more or less that it is very much questionable whether matches of the day, online support, achievements and minor tweaks (which are mostly imported scripts that one could've just downloaded from AoM Heaven or whatever Age of Mythology fan website) such as changing of seasons and "updated graphics" (which are barely notable) are actually worth the money. If you're extremely interested in and devoted to the comeback of random PvP online gameplay within Age of Mythology, then yes, consider getting this. If you're up for amazing new features and fixes to the game other than ranked online modes, I do NOT recommend this, for the new features are barely notable and not worth your money.Why do I recommend this game? Because I'm rating Age of Mythology here, and not the extended edition per se. The game is not bad, the game is actually quite fantastic. It's the extended edition updates that's just not worth the effort in my opinion. In conclusion, Age of Mythology is an all-time classic and must-have for those who enjoyed Age of Empires and other relatively old RTS games. The rules of thumb for purchasing this game are:- IF you're extremely interested in random PvP online Age of Mythology gaming, buy the extended edition. Note that the connection is bad and you will experience a lot of lag.- IF you are a fan of Age of Mythology and want to support the reboot, regardless of the additions being underwhelming, buy the extended edition.- IF you're here for revolutionary RTS experiences and shiny new mechanics, move along.- IF you're not interested in history and mythology, move along.- IF you don't care about the online mode and/or find the additions not impressive, get an old copy of Age of Mythology + the Titans expansion at your game store or online. You can get these old copies for about $2 and they run perfectly fine on ANY XP or higher Windows OS without trouble, and the LAN feature will work fine, so if you want to play with some known friends you can just use a VPN client like Hamachi or Evolve.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Dont get fooled by the positive rates, this game is nothing but a big disappointment and the same story as the remake of Age of Empires II "HD". Someone who rates this game positive is making a giant mistake. People actually think of the original game, which came out in the early 2000' and not the so called "Extended Edition" which is now available on Steam. If people were held to rate only the "new" EE, all the thumbs would go down. Dont get me wrong, the original AoM aswell as AoE II were briliant games which i truly admire. Publishers take an old and sucessful game, dont change anything at all and call it afterwards "HD" or "Extended Edition" to resell it for 10-30€The graphics are the same like in the original game, the resolution of 1920x1080 doesnt fit to the rest of the game.The multiplayer is a complete mess with tons of bugs, crashes, laggs, etc.. It takes forever to start a game cause you cant find other players online and if you get a game finally started, you got 50% chance that you, or anyone else drops or crashes and disc.The game is in no case worth its price of around 30,00€. My recommendation is to get this game on sales for a max. price of 5-8€ or find the original one and install it again.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												NOSTALGIA ALERT!Alongside a other notables mentions such as Age of Empires II and Empire Earth this is literally one of the founding pillars of real-time simulated strategy games. People really need to appreciate that this game comes from 2002 and Steam deserves extra kudos for putting it up on sale. Would recommend this to anyone who likes real-time strategy as it really did set a concrete standard or them earlier on this millennium. Diverse gameplay, I dare say even Age of Empires III may of even glanced over at this at took some of it's ideas >_> One bad thing is that there is a limit on housing and forced limits on town centres so you -pretty- much never get massive battles. Minus that, and expected issues with anything this old, it's a solid game.

												I can't belive I almost didn't buy this because of the amount of recent negative reviews re the game not running etc. I had NO problems running the game on Win7, about 2 years old PC. I experienced NO lagging. I find this to be a good remake of the game I loved as a kid.I think the graphics remake is pretty good, the textures and shadows look nice. Of course, the 3D models would need updating too but I guess that's just a lot of work :) I am happy with the way that it is. Having played recently the original version of this game, I think the remake is really nice.I haven't encountered any single player bugs so far, maybe apart from the unit AI being a stupid from time to time. Basically path finding issues that can be solved with a little micro control.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												Singleplayer:I love the singleplayer campaign and the random maps mode; the story starts off well and the journey through the campaign is a comfortable experience. The random maps mode is a useful and fun game mode if you just want to have fun, it also helps players to understand how the game works with God powers, units and building expansions, etc. it's something worth playing.Multiplayer:Worthless... Every game I play, players love to kill all of my units within seconds to a few minutes, even when I don't have an army prepared. I understand that it is the idea of the game, but I never get given any time to literally do anything. I would stay away from the online part if you're not the type that likes an unfair match; the online mode has no mercy for newcomers.Overall, the main game is fun and entertaining, the online sucks and it has nothing to do with how good one is, it's just an unfair game of kill everyone as soon as the game starts.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												I cannot recommend this version of the game. Currently needs a lot of fixing before I can retracked it.The amount of glitches present at current time is just staggering, not just the visual kind where a wall is half blurry half well textured either. The largest example I just experienced from the original campaign Fall of the Trident: chapter 12 on October 19th 2016 is where some of my units got suck inside my town centre. Before this units got stuck on unwalkable parts of hills as well (still only FotT). Not to mention the visual upgrade is slapdash with Erebus being so dark I thought the greys and blacks got crushed. The added Bloom didn't help either.Have yet to try out the other 2 campeigns, and I do not own the Chinese expansion, although from reading others experience I'm not missing much. Also the rebalance to units feels wrong to me.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												A Long time Favorite Game from off Steam (Execcpt the "Extended Edition" part). I have had Age of Mythology and the Titans Expansion for many a Year, and it STILL is my favorite stratagy game from the earlier years of my life, Playing as the 12 Major Gods Zuse, Poseidon, Hades, Isis, Ra, Set, Odin, Thor, Loki, Kronos, Oranos and Gaia.  All of them Were all fun to play and learn about, along with the Minor Gods, and all of the Mythological Beings such as the Phoenix (Egyptians)or the Automatons (Atlantians) and of course the Minotaur (Greeks).  If You buy this Game, I hope You will learn as much about it and enjoy playing it as much I have in my past.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												AoM was one of the few games that I used to play when I was kid so I decided to try it as I found it on Steam. I read some of the negative feed back, but I thought that crashing happened only if you played with multiplayer.Nope.Game crashes after few hours of playing and naturally destroys everything you have done so far. (You can save the game, but I personally like playing random map games only once.) There is really no point in wasting your money on this as it doesn't work.If this would work, it would be awesome and nostalgic game (with updated grafics and new worlds), but it doesn't so...AoM oli yksi harvoja pelejä, joita nuorempana pelasin, joten päätin nyt kokeilla sitä uudestaan, kun sen Steamista löysin. Lueskelin negatiivisempia arvosteluita, mutta oletin, että viat ja kaatuileminen on lähinnä Online-peleihin.Eipä ollut.Peli lentelee nurin ja hävittää luonnollisesti siinä ohessa kaiken tekemäsi. Pari tuntia kun on pelannut ja sitten tekee näin, niin motivaatio alkaa nopeasti tippua. Ei kannata rahojaan tähän tuhlata, vaan ennemmin muistelee niitä vanhoja hyviä aikoja.Olisi muuten ihan loistava ja nostalginen peli (pieniä päivityksiä on tehty, mutta suurimmalta osalta sama peli kuin ennenkin), mutta se toimivuus...

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
 Age of Make-Me-Some-Cash This game is a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor mess.Who would've thought that an AOM fan such as me wouldn't have minded that expensive £22.99 fee for what this game offers?Multiplayer is laggy as hell, and I've heard that players are taking a dump over the desyncs that make you LOSE ELO (ranking points). Multiplayer ranking matches are effectively a WASTE OF TIME! - 1 hour into the game and the game has already passed the salt onto a once beloved series. This game poured salt onto its self-inflicted wounds.I highly appreciate the efforts made into this game, but there's no way that over in 1 year of development that SkyBox Labs (or Forgotten Empires) can overcome an issue such as losing ranking through just disconnecting your effin' connection cable.This game deserves the epitome of horse dump. Congratulations. DON'T BUY THIS GAME!Buy the original - For multiplayer, use Voobly or Gameranger.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												The original AoM from ye olde disk is fantastic and one of my favorite games of all time. This port, however, is not. It claims to be an "extended" or "enhanced," but manages to look and play worse than the original. I was incredibly excited for the expansion, but was again let down by extensive balance issues that took days or even weeks to fully fix and that a complete newcomer to the game could have diagnosed within their first match. The only redeeming features of this game are that Steam integration makes multiplayer way easier than mucking through Gameranger or Hamachi LAN emulators, and that it runs on Windows 10 (The original version with Safedisk no longer functions on my clean installation of Windows). While this game is absolutely worth playing, try to get the original version to work instead of the Steam version if possible. Although I cannot recommend this game in good conscience, I will continue to play it for the forseeable future as a (barely) functional substitute.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Pretty sad bottom line for a remake. Adds nothing of value to the original. Having to pay $30 for the addition of community mods that are available for free is a disgrace. 8/10 for the game itself which is a pretty good RTS , 0/10 for the low move from MS studios. Buy the Gold Edition for less than $10 and save yourselves the trouble.About the dlc:Another low budget piece of junk from Ensemble Studio.Let me tell you why this is a low budget piece of junk. I have played so many RTS games and never have seen a game where the hardest level is unplayable to me. It is obvious the game designers have never played the Titan level because it is simply not playable. This is due to the low budget nature of this game and the developers have not enough time to test the game's balance. Normally within 5-10 minutes of the game, you are rushed with pre-built(not built within time frame of the game) large group of enemies, which is all but impossible to beat due to the short time frame. What is worse, sometimes this large group of enemy appears within about 5 minutes, in which time you have built less than 10 workers! To make things worse, the AI has infinite resources and every 5 minutes it sends you a large group of enemies, but on your side, you have finite resources which means even if you manage to beat the first few waves, you exhaust your resources within less than 30 minutes but AI has infinite resources, the waves the AI sends you are infinite. The whole thing is ill designed. Also, the games has appalling routing algorithm and units often get stuck on map. Also controlling the units are very clumsy, for example the "attack move" move which is the bread and butter of the RTS games does not seem to work. It either worked like normal move or gets the units stuck. From these details you can definitely tell this is a low budget rushed product. Age of Empire 3 from the same company is about the same type of low budget junk

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												Age of Mythology is one of the RTS games that everyone who could use a computer in the early 2000's has played. It is an undeniable classic. All the more reason to give it a new paintjob for the next decade. Skybox has been busy bringing most of Microsoft's classic strategy names to the high definintion screen. A graphical tough up here, some upscaling there, a new netcode, steam intergration, and some more funny stuff, but when you compare it to the original version, you're going to be dissapointed. I still own the disk for Age of Mythology and it runs like a purring kitten on my laptop. This updated HD version...barely any improvement. It is still very much the same game. Basically the devs went to the game and replaced its parts with modern, more durable ones. Kinda like going into a house and replacing all the lightbulbs with LEDs and replacing the TV with flatscreen. It is superficial, and it doesn't even come close to justify its outrageous pricepoint. The game itself is still stiff, the voice acting weird and many of units that look impressive lack the punch you'd expect. What skybox has done is put new wheels and paint on a classic hot rod old it as new while the ride has gotten awful over the years and tires spin out when you try to pull away.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												IT'S HAPPENING!?!?!?!?For many of us Age of Mythology is a game very close to our hearts. For those unfamiliar with the game, it is essentially a Real Time Strategy game, much like Age of Empires - but with heroes and mythical units too. While their are only four main factions to choose from (greek, egyptian, norse, atlanteans), each faction has numerous gods to choose from, and the diversity of not only the mythical units, but the standard human units as well, is impressive.The single player campaign is very well designed, with good level design throughout, and you will want to play it through more than once. While the Multiplayer is where the true fun lies, the single player is still worthy as a stand-alone game. Do not be afraid of trying out multiplayer though. Sure - there will be some very good people playing online, but do not be disheartened. Soon you will be (and I'm sure many of us have already experienced this) spending countless hours trying different game modes and developing new strategies to crush the heathan(s) opposing you. Also if you can get some mates together to play then all the merrier!Even though there appear to be some technical issues with the steam edition, let us just hope that they work out similar to those that were present in the Age of Empires Steam edition (which have since been fixed).If you have not experienced Age of Mythology, then I would whole-heartedly recommend it. If you have already played it then you may be a bit sceptical about handing out money for something you already own. What you are really paying for is the steam support for multiplayer. Finding games to play will be much simpler, because I can assure you that there will be a lot of people playing this game. A great game with an active and passionate community should not be simply passed by.9/10 would nostalgia again.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Gameplay is virtually unchanged since its original release in 2002, leaving the balance (or unbalance) of the game intact. Because of this, and since the original game still runs on modern computers in HD resolutions, I'll be focusing entirely on what this installment brings to the table. 1. Improved visuals: But not really.Much like the AoE2 re-release, Mythology was given a visual overhaul by the new studio. What this means is that they've tacked on new graphical features, without much considering of how this will benefit players. You'll see things such as GLOBAL LIGHTING and BLURRY WATER FILTER. Whether these really improve anything lies mostly in the eyes of the beholder; but for those who played the original, the new look will be discomforting and sometimes hindering (on certain maps, your units will be difficult to see).2. Social gaming: A.k.a. the "Steam Experience".Because custom maps is half the fun, right? Again, highly subjective, but unlike the visual improvements, this is actually a feature that is only beneficial, and does not hinder anyone who's not interested in it. So, in that sense, this is the best thing to come out of the Extended Edition. However, it does not - and will not ever - weigh heavily enough to be worthy of the 30€ price tag. But what about all the other awesome Steam-exlusive features that you won't find in the original 2002 release? Because a PC game without achievements and trading cards doesn't belong in 2014 - said no one ever, probably. You were fine without achievements in 2002, and you were fine without Steam trading cards in 2012. But the cloud saves! The clooooouuud saaaves! Oh god, yes! Finally I can sync my save files to the web, for instant access. No, it's a decent feature, but like the workshop, hardly a worthy selling point. 3. Extended Features: Watch other people play.Just as Age 2 HD was given Twitch Integration, Mythology was as well. This is a rising trend in video games, and I can't see anything wrong with it. Is it a necessary feature for the re-release of a 12 year old game? Probably not; but it doesn't hurt. But - and this seems to be the theme of this review - it is hardly worth the 30€ price tag. Streaming to Twitch is free with software like OBS, and also provides tenfolds more options than any integrated feature ever will. In conclusion: Don't waste your moneyUnlike the Age 2 re-release, this one is not needed - unless maybe you're among the relatively few hardcore Mythology players, that has also grown tired using 3rd party applications for online matchmaking, enough so that you are willing to throw 30€ at the unstoppable Remake-All-The-Games machine. If not, then pass on this one. It's an older game that still works fine on modern machines, and supports larger resolutions out of the box. Pick it up at a local game shop for a couple of bucks instead. You'll be better off.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Gameplay is virtually unchanged since its original release in 2002, leaving the balance (or unbalance) of the game intact. Because of this, and since the original game still runs on modern computers in HD resolutions, I'll be focusing entirely on what this installment brings to the table. 1. Improved visuals: But not really.Much like the AoE2 re-release, Mythology was given a visual overhaul by the new studio. What this means is that they've tacked on new graphical features, without much considering of how this will benefit players. You'll see things such as GLOBAL LIGHTING and BLURRY WATER FILTER. Whether these really improve anything lies mostly in the eyes of the beholder; but for those who played the original, the new look will be discomforting and sometimes hindering (on certain maps, your units will be difficult to see).2. Social gaming: A.k.a. the "Steam Experience".Because custom maps is half the fun, right? Again, highly subjective, but unlike the visual improvements, this is actually a feature that is only beneficial, and does not hinder anyone who's not interested in it. So, in that sense, this is the best thing to come out of the Extended Edition. However, it does not - and will not ever - weigh heavily enough to be worthy of the 30€ price tag. But what about all the other awesome Steam-exlusive features that you won't find in the original 2002 release? Because a PC game without achievements and trading cards doesn't belong in 2014 - said no one ever, probably. You were fine without achievements in 2002, and you were fine without Steam trading cards in 2012. But the cloud saves! The clooooouuud saaaves! Oh god, yes! Finally I can sync my save files to the web, for instant access. No, it's a decent feature, but like the workshop, hardly a worthy selling point. 3. Extended Features: Watch other people play.Just as Age 2 HD was given Twitch Integration, Mythology was as well. This is a rising trend in video games, and I can't see anything wrong with it. Is it a necessary feature for the re-release of a 12 year old game? Probably not; but it doesn't hurt. But - and this seems to be the theme of this review - it is hardly worth the 30€ price tag. Streaming to Twitch is free with software like OBS, and also provides tenfolds more options than any integrated feature ever will. In conclusion: Don't waste your moneyUnlike the Age 2 re-release, this one is not needed - unless maybe you're among the relatively few hardcore Mythology players, that has also grown tired using 3rd party applications for online matchmaking, enough so that you are willing to throw 30€ at the unstoppable Remake-All-The-Games machine. If not, then pass on this one. It's an older game that still works fine on modern machines, and supports larger resolutions out of the box. Pick it up at a local game shop for a couple of bucks instead. You'll be better off.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Not bad, bu had to say i expected a little more. The repackage on this is priceless. "EXTENDED EDITION" isn't really tuned up to anything special. It seems like they literally just put in the maps for the next expansion (The all too common, "upgrade to play this!") as a carrot on a stick for Dragon.  Oh, and NIGHT AND DAY GUYS. haha.You still have some pretty herp a derp AI and building kinks that are true to the original.  My units still love going around my city, when i have perfectly good gates X D If this is a game you miss having on your shelf,  you enjoy the mechanics of the Age of Empires games, and or have a hard on for good mythology... Buy it if it's on sale. have to say it's worth the 7 dollars i payed.If you havent played these games yet and this one caught your eye, keep a few things in mind. The campaign really isn't anything spectacular, and it lacks the depth that many other RTS have that are available for a competitive price. There's no real negotiating trades or territories or treaties. Diplomacy is clicking to go to war.Nation-building is insanely straightforward. Laborers gather each supply, and theres very few to keep track of. Food, gold, wood, favor, population. You dont have to keep them happy or worry about maintaining them (save from your enemies wrathful armies)Combat isn't anything flashy, little units slash at eachother. There are a few little tactical things you can make them do but nothing compared to some of the other RTS games you might have played. Tl;drFun and simple RTS for all skill groups, great mythology and skirmish play. Campaign lacks luster and the "Extended Edition" just feels like Titans with added teasers for the Dragon Expansion. Worth a couple bucks if it's on sale(I got mine for seven dollars and that seems like a fair price).BoogaBooga.
